A monumental game in my gaming career, Half-Life 2 was that defining experience that made me realise I was in for something next level. For the first time i picked it up on The Orange Box in 2008, and from the moment I booted it up, I knew I was in for a wild ride. It wasn‚Äôt just a game‚Äîit was an event. The environments were absolutely massive, the atmosphere was unreal, and the soundtrack? Edgy as hell. Every moment felt like a cinematic journey.

In Half-Life 2, you play as Gordon Freeman, arguably one of the most reluctant action heroes in gaming. You awaken from stasis, burdened with the trauma of the previous game, and are immediately thrust into action as the figurehead of an uprising. This isn‚Äôt a simple revolution‚Äîit‚Äôs a battle against a multiversal alien threat, shrouded in dystopian themes and orchestrated by secretive organizations manipulating events behind the scenes.

Set in a world dominated by the Combine, an alien regime that combines interdimensional authoritarianism with advanced technology, you must navigate a planet under their control. Armed with little more than a crowbar and your signature nonverbalism, Gordon becomes the key figure in the resistance. As you progress, you'll engage in intense combat, solve puzzles, explore diverse environments, and uncover the unsettling truth that nothing in this world is as it seems.

And let‚Äôs talk about The G-Man‚Äîa mysterious, interdimensional CIA glowman who pops up like a bad dream and probably controls the entire charade like a cosmic puppeteer. Is he good? Is he bad? Is he just playing the long game? Who knows, but he‚Äôs definitely got his hand in everything, watching Gordon like a hawk, pulling strings like an invisible god. 

You‚Äôd think it‚Äôs just a sci-fi conspiracy, but after a while, you start questioning if anyone really knows what the hell is going on. Does G-Man even have a purpose, or is he just a cosmic observer who gets his kicks out of watching a man with a crowbar take on the end of the world?

The game‚Äôs narrative feels like a giant puzzle, and each step forward opens up even more questions, all while you‚Äôre tearing through enemy lines, trying to get answers. And the best part? It‚Äôs not all about combat‚Äîthere are puzzles to solve, mysteries to uncover, and a sense of isolation that keeps you on edge, constantly wondering who or what will show up next. The pacing is incredible, making you feel like you‚Äôre a tiny piece of something far larger, with consequences that span across dimensions.

Released in 2004 by Valve, it redefined what players could expect from a video game in terms of both storytelling and gameplay. The game‚Äôs narrative is immersive, unfolding without traditional cutscenes, which allows the player to feel like they are truly part of the story. The protagonist, Gordon Freeman, is a silent hero who navigates through a dystopian world filled with alien invaders and oppressive human forces. This unique approach to storytelling pulls the player into the game‚Äôs world, making every action feel meaningful.

The physics engine in "Half-Life 2" was revolutionary for its time. The way objects interact with the environment feels natural and intuitive, and it became a major part of the gameplay. From solving puzzles using physics to creatively using the environment as a weapon, it was an innovation that influenced many games that followed. The gravity gun, which allows players to manipulate objects in real-time, is still one of the most memorable and fun weapons in gaming history.

The level design in "Half-Life 2" is another standout feature. The game introduces players to varied environments, from the dark, industrial city of City 17 to the eerie, remote marshlands. Each location feels carefully crafted, with attention to detail that makes the world feel alive. The pacing is also masterful, alternating between moments of intense combat and slower, atmospheric sequences that allow the player to soak in the environment and story.

The AI in "Half-Life 2" was also ahead of its time. Enemies behave intelligently, using cover, working together, and reacting to the player‚Äôs actions in a way that makes combat more dynamic and challenging. The enemy variety, from the terrifying Combine soldiers to the creepy headcrabs, keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging. The interactions with NPCs and the world around you help build a sense of tension and immersion, keeping you on edge throughout the experience.

The game's soundtrack, composed by Kelly Bailey, perfectly complements the atmosphere, using subtle but effective music to enhance both the action and the quieter moments. The sound design is top-notch, with ambient sounds adding to the immersion, whether you're in a busy city street or exploring a deserted warehouse.

Ultimately, "Half-Life 2" is a masterpiece that still holds up to this day. Its innovative gameplay, storytelling, and technical achievements make it a game that set a new standard for the industry. It‚Äôs a game that‚Äôs not just fun to play, but one that‚Äôs easy to appreciate for the way it shaped the future of video games. Even though it‚Äôs been years since its release, "Half-Life 2" remains a classic that continues to inspire both players and developers alike.

Half-Life: Deathmatch: Source is a multiplayer first-person shooter developed by Valve. It is a remake of the classic Half-Life deathmatch mode, utilizing the Source engine. The game combines the fast-paced action of traditional deathmatch with updated graphics and more fluid movement mechanics. While it successfully brings new life to the original concept, some mechanical issues and a niche player base prevent it from being as popular as its predecessors.

What Works Well?
üéÆ Classic Deathmatch Gameplay
The core of Half-Life: Deathmatch is its tight, fast-paced combat. It stays true to the original deathmatch mode, offering classic weapons, high-speed action, and simple, enjoyable mechanics. The formula remains as fun today as it was when first introduced.

üåÜ Updated Graphics with Source Engine
The move to the Source engine has significantly improved the visuals compared to the original. The lighting, textures, and models are much sharper, breathing new life into the iconic Half-Life universe. The environments feel more immersive, and physics interactions are more dynamic.

üî´ Familiar Weapon Set
Players have access to a variety of classic weapons from the Half-Life series, including the crowbar, shotgun, and crossbow, all of which perform as expected. Each weapon has its own strategic value, and they all function well within the confines of the deathmatch setting.

üõ†Ô∏è Modding Support and Custom Servers
As with other Source engine games, Deathmatch: Source allows for a robust modding community. Players can easily find custom servers and user-created content, from new maps to modified gameplay modes, keeping the experience fresh.

What Could Be Better?
‚ùå Limited Popularity and Player Base
Despite its solid foundation, Half-Life: Deathmatch: Source suffers from a relatively small player base. As newer games in the genre continue to dominate, it can be difficult to find active matches, especially in more niche servers.

‚ùå Physics Can Feel Clunky
While the Source engine improved many aspects of the game, some of the physics‚Äîespecially in terms of movement‚Äîcan feel a little awkward compared to modern shooters. The transition to 3D space feels a bit more restrictive than anticipated, particularly when compared to the fluidity of more modern games.

‚ùå No Significant Gameplay Innovation
While the updated graphics and better physics are great, Deathmatch: Source doesn't introduce any major changes to the original formula. It feels more like a polished port rather than a revolutionary step forward for the genre. Players expecting something drastically new may be disappointed.

‚ùå Lack of Meaningful Progression
Like many classic deathmatch games, there‚Äôs a lack of meaningful progression or any form of unlockable content. While this keeps the focus on pure skill-based play, some players may miss the more modern systems that reward long-term engagement.

Conclusion
Half-Life: Deathmatch: Source is a solid multiplayer shooter for fans of the classic Half-Life experience. Its updated visuals and iconic weapons deliver the fun, high-speed action that fans love, but its small player base and lack of major innovation hold it back from achieving greater popularity. If you‚Äôre looking for nostalgic deathmatch action or enjoy modding, it‚Äôs a great choice, but don‚Äôt expect a revolutionary experience.

Burnout Paradise: The Ultimate Box is a revolutionary arcade racing game that takes the Burnout series into a free-roaming open world. Released in 2008 by Criterion Games, the game offers fast-paced, destructive racing with an emphasis on stunts and crazy crashes, all set in a vast and dynamic city. The Ultimate Box includes the base game as well as all the downloadable content (DLC) released up until that point, making it the definitive version for those who want to experience the entire game.

What Works Well?
üöó Open-World Racing
The game‚Äôs open-world structure sets it apart from other racing games at the time. Rather than following a linear progression, players can freely drive around the fictional Paradise City, discovering races, challenges, and events. The world is vast, lively, and packed with dynamic content, making it feel alive and exciting.

üí• Destruction and Crashes
Burnout is known for its over-the-top crashes, and Paradise delivers on that in spades. The game has a Crashing system that encourages players to drive recklessly, with spectacular visual effects when you crash into other cars, barriers, or objects. Burnouts are highly satisfying and one of the game‚Äôs most memorable features.

üèÅ Variety of Race Types and Events
The game offers a wide variety of events that are not limited to traditional races. Players can engage in Road Rage (taking out opponents), Marked Man (escaping pursuers), Stunt Runs, and more. Each event type presents its own challenge, and the more you play, the more you unlock new events, keeping things fresh and exciting.

üé∂ Fantastic Soundtrack
The soundtrack of Burnout Paradise is a crowd-pleaser, featuring a varied mix of rock, punk, and electronic music, with tracks that fit perfectly with the high-energy racing. The dynamic soundtrack also changes depending on the events you‚Äôre engaged in, further immersing you in the experience.

What Could Be Better?
‚ùå Controls May Feel Loose to Some
While the game‚Äôs arcade-style driving can be thrilling, some players may find the controls a little loose compared to more simulation-based racers. Steering is forgiving, and the game allows you to perform wild drifts, but it may not be as satisfying for players who prefer a more precise racing experience.

‚ùå No Split-Screen Multiplayer
One major downside for local multiplayer fans is the lack of split-screen racing. While Burnout Paradise offers online multiplayer, the absence of local co-op or versus racing may be a dealbreaker for those who enjoy couch multiplayer.

‚ùå Aging Graphics
Though the game looked fantastic at launch, the graphics can appear dated when compared to newer racing games. While the art style is still charming, the textures and vehicle models may not impress modern gamers who are accustomed to hyper-realistic visuals.

Conclusion
Burnout Paradise: The Ultimate Box is a masterpiece of arcade racing that delivers adrenaline-pumping fun and creative destruction. The open-world format, spectacular crashes, and variety of events make it one of the most entertaining racing games of its time. Though it may not have the sharpest visuals or the most precise controls, its fast-paced, chaotic gameplay more than makes up for it. If you love open-world racing or are a fan of the Burnout series, Burnout Paradise: The Ultimate Box is an absolute must-play.

 | The game also comes with a DLC, which includes the following items:

1. A Toxic Community: Mistakes are rarely forgiven. Unless you‚Äôre playing with friends, be prepared to face harsh criticism, often from younger players. The game‚Äôs multiplayer is largely populated by school-aged players who don‚Äôt hold back.


2. Disruptive Adults: It‚Äôs not just the kids causing chaos‚Äîsome adults blast music through their microphones, assuming everyone else shares their taste. Spoiler: they don‚Äôt.


3. Frequent AFKs: Teamwork can fall apart when a teammate goes inactive, whether they‚Äôre brewing tea, taking a smoke break, or simply wandering off mid-game. And yes, it often happens right after you‚Äôve generously used your first aid kit on them.


4. Team Abandonment: Lone wolves running off to the far corners of the map, only to be overwhelmed by infected, are a common sight. They‚Äôre quick to flood the chat with colorful language before rage-quitting the game.


5. Difficulty Disputes: Some players join games on "Expert" difficulty only to demand a downgrade. If their request is denied, they might sabotage the team before leaving the server entirely.


6. Vote Kicks: Occasionally, you‚Äôll encounter players who inexplicably start a vote to kick you from the game. When you ask why? Crickets.



The Verdict: Despite the chaotic community, Left 4 Dead 2 remains a phenomenal experience. The graphics are a significant step up from the first game, the mechanics feel more polished, and there‚Äôs a greater variety of weapons and infected to enjoy. However, surviving the online experience without a calming remedy might be just as challenging as surviving the zombie apocalypse itself. | Left 4 Dead 2 (L4D2), released by Valve in 2009, is the gold standard for cooperative zombie shooters. Featuring intense survival gameplay, smart AI, and an incredible atmosphere, L4D2 delivers an unmatched multiplayer experience. With its fast-paced action, diverse weapons, and unpredictable enemy encounters, this game remains one of the most thrilling and replayable co-op shooters ever made.

Gameplay ‚Äì Pure, Adrenaline-Fueled Action
L4D2 is all about co-op survival. You and three teammates must fight through hordes of the undead, navigating through various maps and completing objectives to reach safety. The key to survival? Teamwork, strategy, and adaptability.

The gunplay is tight and satisfying, with a wide selection of weapons including assault rifles, shotguns, SMGs, sniper rifles, and melee weapons like axes, katanas, and even frying pans! Every encounter feels dynamic, thanks to the AI Director, which adjusts the difficulty based on your team‚Äôs performance, ensuring no two playthroughs are ever the same.

Special Infected ‚Äì Enemies That Keep You on Edge
Beyond the standard zombie horde, L4D2 introduces Special Infected that force players to work together:

Tank ‚Äì A massive brute that can throw debris and crush survivors.
Witch ‚Äì A terrifying enemy that, if startled, can instantly incapacitate a survivor.
Smoker ‚Äì Uses a long tongue to drag players away from their team.
Hunter ‚Äì A fast, agile infected that pounces on survivors and pins them down.
Boomer ‚Äì Explodes in a shower of bile, attracting a massive horde.
Charger ‚Äì Charges through groups, slamming a survivor into the ground.
Spitter ‚Äì Creates pools of acid that deal heavy damage.
Each Special Infected forces different team strategies, making communication and positioning absolutely crucial.

Campaigns & Maps ‚Äì A Horror Movie Experience
L4D2 features multiple campaigns, each set in diverse, apocalyptic locations across the southern U.S.:

Dead Center ‚Äì A chaotic mall escape reminiscent of classic zombie films.
The Parish ‚Äì A tense race across New Orleans to reach an evacuation zone.
Swamp Fever ‚Äì A creepy, foggy swamp filled with infected dangers.
Hard Rain ‚Äì A unique campaign featuring a devastating hurricane that changes the environment.
Dark Carnival ‚Äì A fan-favorite, featuring a deadly amusement park with a thrilling rollercoaster finale.
Each campaign feels like a mini zombie movie, packed with cinematic set pieces, interactive environments, and intense finales.

Multiplayer & Game Modes ‚Äì Endless Replayability
L4D2 offers several game modes that keep the action fresh:

Campaign Mode ‚Äì Classic co-op survival through story-driven levels.
Versus Mode ‚Äì One team plays as survivors, while the other controls the Special Infected.
Survival Mode ‚Äì See how long you can last against endless waves of zombies.
Scavenge Mode ‚Äì A competitive mode where teams race to collect fuel cans while being hunted.
Mutation Mode ‚Äì Weekly game modifiers that add fun twists to gameplay.
Thanks to modding support and the Steam Workshop, the community has also created hundreds of custom maps, weapons, and campaigns, making L4D2‚Äôs replayability practically infinite.

Graphics & Sound ‚Äì Immersive and Timeless
Even years after release, L4D2‚Äôs atmospheric lighting, detailed environments, and gruesome effects hold up well. Zombies react realistically to gunfire, and the sound design is masterful, with eerie background noises, terrifying growls from Special Infected, and intense musical cues that heighten the suspense.

The voice acting and character interactions bring the survivors to life, making them memorable and adding humor to the chaos.

Why Left 4 Dead 2 is a Must-Play
L4D2 is the perfect blend of action, horror, and co-op gameplay. Whether you‚Äôre playing with friends or AI teammates, the intense combat, unpredictable enemy encounters, and endless replayability make every match a thrilling adventure.

üîπ Final Rating: 10/10
Left 4 Dead 2 is a masterpiece of cooperative gaming. If you love zombies, action, and teamwork, this is an absolute must-play that still delivers endless fun and excitement after more than a decade.

Certified classic. Total OG game. Gameplay, graphics, art style and direction, music, vibes, and main character. All great!

Also, if the game crashes right after the tutorial/prologue, make sure you disable PhysX or w.e in the settings. | It's one of the greatest classic games ever, yet it remains one of the most innovative. Not to mention its sleek and polished design, along with its captivating parkour action and thrilling gameplay, which make it truly one of a kind. | [h2] Pros [/h2]

1. First things first, kudos to the devs for making a non-sexualised female mc back in the day against the norms (even if it was today, we all know a large portion of "Gamers" would lose their mind screaming DEI and woke lol). 

2. Secondly, the art direction is superb and it shows that stylistic approach stands the test of time better than realism (look at any REALISTIC graphics game from back then that people lost their shit over, now they just look ugly af). 

3. The parkour is unique, feels great to play on controller, and is easy to learn but hard to master. When you pull off some cool wallrun-turn-jump-walllrun combo, you'd feel like a total badass.

4. The voice actors have done a terrific job giving personality to the characters. I really enjoys Merc's voice guiding me through the levels, and the others were NOT far worse too.

[h2] Cons [/h2]

1. The story is dogshit. It works well enough to connect one parkouring stage to another, but don't go in expecting any story that might emotionally involve you lol.

2. The combat sections feel unnecessary and underdeveloped. Maybe it's just my problem, but I felt like the game would've been better if they scraped the combat totally and added a few more parkouring challenged instead.

[h2] Some points to note [/h2]

1. The game is short. I died a lot of times, stayed afk during game time watching game of thrones (lol) and yet i completed the game under 6 and a 1/2 hours. It might be a deal breaker for some, but I think this was well worth the money.

2. When you play, turn OFF the PhysX, or the game would suffer severe framerate drop everytime a glass shatters (any combat section, really).

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]

Albeit short and emotionally not gripping, Mirror's edge boasts fun and unique gameplay with great visuals to date and a pure good fun time. I recommend this.

Portal 2 is one of the best puzzle games ever created. It combines logical thinking, physics-based mechanics, and an engaging story. The game takes place in Aperture Science, a mysterious and dangerous laboratory filled with test chambers. The player controls Chell, a silent protagonist who must escape using the Portal Gun. This device allows players to create two linked portals on surfaces, making it possible to teleport and solve puzzles.

One of the most impressive aspects of Portal 2 is its level design. Each test chamber introduces new mechanics, forcing players to think creatively. The game starts with simple puzzles but gradually becomes more complex. Elements like light bridges, propulsion gel, and lasers add depth to the challenges. The difficulty curve is perfect, making the game enjoyable for both beginners and experienced players.

Portal 2 also stands out with its story and humor. The main antagonist, GLaDOS, is a sarcastic and witty AI who constantly insults and manipulates the player. Wheatley, a clumsy and funny robot, adds another layer of comedy. Their dialogues make the game more entertaining and memorable. Despite its humor, the story also explores themes of control, identity, and artificial intelligence.

Another great feature of Portal 2 is its cooperative mode. Unlike the single-player campaign, co-op requires teamwork and communication. Players control two robots, Atlas and P-Body, solving puzzles that require coordination. This mode enhances the experience, making it even more enjoyable when played with a friend.

Overall, Portal

The game's got an incredible replay value, thanks to the shitload of items and upgrades available, all the different unlockable characters, all the great bosses and secrets to uncover, the dark and unsettling lore and story, and all the alternate endings. It's a very challenging game, even frustrating at times, as it can feel almost impossible (some of the final bosses are really tough, and you really need to memorize their attack patterns), but it's a really great game if you take your time to learn it. The art-style is grotesque, and the atmosphere is oppressing, but these things combined work well with the somewhat bleak world and characters. Given the game's roguelike nature, RNG can sometimes fuck you big time, and some runs kind of feel doomed from the start; other times you get fucked towards the end, but there's always something new to find or to unlock, so no run feels completely wasted. My only real complaint with this version is that at times the performance is kinda shit as the game lags/feels unresponsive at times (maybe because it was made in Flash, not really sure), and you can die due to stuff out of your control.

Still, The Binding of Isaac's a classic and really worth the price. | playing this game on the school computers on a browser was so fun, would recommend if you like the classic NES Zelda game | 8/10 O jogo √© muito bom, leve e divertido para passar o tempo. Overview: ORION: Prelude is a first-person shooter and survival game developed by Spiral Game Studios. Set in a sci-fi universe, the game offers players the chance to fight off waves of enemies, mine for resources, and explore alien landscapes. As the "Prelude" in the title suggests, this is part of a larger series that focuses on cooperative survival and exploration. Players can engage in solo or multiplayer modes, with the game offering various environments and enemies to battle.

Gameplay: At its core, ORION: Prelude is a mix of survival, exploration, and action. The game features dynamic combat, where players fight off hordes of enemies with a variety of weapons and tools. Players can also mine resources to improve their weapons, build turrets, and upgrade their defenses.

The game supports both solo and multiplayer modes, with the co-op experience being a major highlight. In multiplayer, players can team up to face increasingly difficult waves of enemies. This cooperative play adds a layer of strategy, as players need to work together to survive the onslaught.

The combat itself is relatively standard for a first-person shooter, with a variety of weapons available, including guns, explosives, and melee tools. However, the AI can sometimes feel lackluster, and the enemy design doesn‚Äôt offer much variety or challenge in the long run.

Graphics and Performance: ORION: Prelude features fairly basic graphics for a modern first-person shooter. The environments are passable but not particularly impressive, with alien landscapes that can feel repetitive. The textures and character models are simple, and while they‚Äôre functional, they don't stand out visually. The game‚Äôs visual style is somewhat dated, even by the standards of games released around its time.

In terms of performance, ORION: Prelude runs decently on most systems, but it can struggle with optimization at times. Some players report frame rate drops or occasional stuttering, especially in more intense combat scenarios or when there are many enemies on screen. While the game isn't demanding on hardware, the performance can still be inconsistent, which may detract from the experience.

Audio Design: The audio in ORION: Prelude is serviceable but not remarkable. The sound effects for weapons, explosions, and enemies are decent but don‚Äôt have a strong impact. The soundtrack is fairly generic, with ambient sci-fi tunes that don‚Äôt add much to the atmosphere. While the audio isn't distracting, it doesn‚Äôt elevate the experience either. There‚Äôs no significant voice acting, which could have added personality and immersion to the game‚Äôs characters and story.

Challenges: ORION: Prelude offers a moderate challenge, especially in survival mode. As players progress through waves of enemies, the difficulty increases, requiring players to manage resources, defend positions, and upgrade their gear. However, the lack of diverse enemy types or complex AI behavior can make the game feel repetitive over time.

The game can become quite grindy, as players need to farm resources, mine, and continuously upgrade their weapons and defenses. While this can be fun for a while, it may begin to feel monotonous, especially if playing solo.

Final Thoughts: ORION: Prelude is an ambitious, yet somewhat flawed, survival shooter. While the cooperative gameplay and resource management offer some fun, the overall experience can feel repetitive and lacks the depth needed to keep players fully engaged. The game‚Äôs dated graphics, lack of enemy variety, and inconsistent performance hold it back from being a standout title in the genre.

Pros:

Fun cooperative multiplayer with friends
Resource management and upgrading add strategic elements
Some decent combat mechanics
Fairly easy to jump into for casual play
Cons:

Dated graphics and repetitive environments
Weak AI and lackluster enemy variety
Performance issues, including frame drops and stuttering
Lack of story or deep character development
Can become grindy and repetitive over time

–í —Ü–µ–ª–æ–º, Crysis 2 ‚Äì —ç—Ç–æ –∏–≥—Ä–∞, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä–∞—è –∑–∞—Å–ª—É–∂–∏–≤–∞–µ—Ç –≤–Ω–∏–º–∞–Ω–∏—è –Ω–µ —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –∑–∞ —Å—á–µ—Ç –≥—Ä–∞—Ñ–∏–∫–∏, –Ω–æ –∏ –±–ª–∞–≥–æ–¥–∞—Ä—è —É–≤–ª–µ–∫–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ–º—É –≥–µ–π–º–ø–ª–µ—é –∏ –∫—Ä—É—Ç–æ–π –∞—Ç–º–æ—Å—Ñ–µ—Ä–µ. –î–∞–∂–µ —Å–µ–π—á–∞—Å –æ–Ω–∞ –æ—Ç–ª–∏—á–Ω–æ –∏–≥—Ä–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –∏ –ø—Ä–∏–Ω–æ—Å–∏—Ç –º–∞—Å—Å—É —É–¥–æ–≤–æ–ª—å—Å—Ç–≤–∏—è. | Crysis 2 set out to take everything that made its predecessor a technical marvel and refine it into a more accessible, fast-paced shooter. 
And while it certainly delivers some thrilling moments and impressive visuals, it doesn‚Äôt quite recapture the open-world jungle stealth that made the first game so iconic.
The change in setting from the jungle to an urban environment is a bold shift, but it introduces a more linear structure that feels somewhat restrictive, especially for those who loved the sandbox-style freedom of the first game. 
New York itself is a beautifully detailed war zone, but it‚Äôs a far cry from the lush, expansive jungles of Crysis.
One of the standout features of Crysis 2 is, unsurprisingly, its visual fidelity. 
The game is absolutely stunning, with some of the best lighting and detailed textures of its time. 
The city‚Äôs towering skyscrapers and desolate streets look phenomenal, with dynamic weather and destruction adding to the immersion. 
If you‚Äôre playing it on a capable machine, it‚Äôs easy to get lost in the beauty of it all.
The Nanosuit still provides a range of abilities, but this time, combat is much more action-focused. 
The addition of a more streamlined experience, including quicker movements, tight corridors, and intense firefights, turns Crysis 2 into a more traditional first-person shooter. 
While the cloak and armor abilities are still enjoyable, the focus on tighter levels and less open-ended gameplay doesn‚Äôt give you the same sense of power or freedom as the first game did. 
The game feels more like a "shoot 'em up" than the strategic, stealth-based experience that Crysis offered.
Combat itself is solid, with well-designed weapons and enemy AI that offers a decent challenge. 
The alien enemies, while interesting and varied, don‚Äôt evoke the same awe as the ones in the first game, and their repetitive design often makes encounters feel formulaic. 
The inclusion of human enemies, however, brings a decent level of variety to the action.
Unfortunately, the narrative doesn‚Äôt do much to elevate the experience. 
The plot feels like a typical alien invasion story, and the characters, including Alcatraz, are flat and lack the emotional depth that would have made the stakes feel more meaningful.
All in all, Crysis 2 is a game with plenty of technical polish and high-octane action, but it falls short of recapturing the magic of the original. 
The switch to a more linear structure, coupled with a less captivating story, makes it feel more like a solid shooter than the genre-defining experience the first game was.
If you're in it for the action and beautiful visuals, Crysis 2 delivers. 
But if you were hoping for the same kind of immersive, open-world stealth and freedom that made the original such a standout, you may find yourself a bit disappointed.

But despite it all - it's a beautiful story. I enjoyed it a lot - it has funny jokes and moments, and wholesome, heartwarming parts, and very sad ones... Definitely worth playing, maybe buy on sale - full price is a bit much for amount of content.

An unique experience. Possibly the best puzzle game I've played. Highly recommend.

The game is not linear. The map is kinda like a maze. You will often reach dead ends and will have to come back once you have new tools, or more knowledge. It's kinda like a metroidvania in this regard.

Also similar to The Witness in a way as you will periodically uncover new mechanics on your own and get a better understanding of the world. | This is among the best surreal puzzle games I've played. The graphics are simple, effective, and occasionally hypnotically gorgeous. The puzzles are challenging. I managed to get through the game with no outside help which is rare for me, but it was not easy, and I spent several minutes at a time just staring at my screen trying to figure out a solution to whatever was in front of me. You would like this game if you've enjoyed games like Chroma Zero or Myst. | Really fun and cool puzzle game. Encourages lots of out of the box thinking and gives interesting life lessons about problem solving.
4/5 | A very cool puzzle game based around learning more about the rules of the world than collecting new items or whatever. | One of the best puzzle games I've played. makes you think in, out and all around the box. The Banner Saga: Factions ist der Free-to-Play Multiplayer-Ableger von The Banner Saga. Im Kern haben wir hier ein rundenbasiertes Arena-Taktikspiel vor uns. So sch√∂n auch Banner Saga ist, hier kommt nicht wirklich Stimmung auf. Das eigentliche Spiel lebt von seiner tollen Geschichte, die aber hier keine Wirkung entfaltet. Wir dreschen uns einfach mit √§hnlichen Gruppen herum. Das zieht sich teilweise erheblich. Hauptproblem sind letztlich aber die kaum vorhandenen Mitspieler. Schade das man nicht auf die Idee kam auch Koop-PvE und Bots als Ersatz f√ºr menschliche Gegner f√ºr PvP einzuf√ºgen. Das h√§tte dem Spiel gut getan. So ist das Spiel letztlich eine Art Demo-Version f√ºr die K√§mpfe von Banner Saga.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZBYxV-1eFKU | The Banner Saga: Factions revolves around the first part of the banner saga story, in which you are permanently stuck inside one area of the story, fighting battles in a bar against others in a multiplayer tactics game. This game has a ton of potential to grow, and can be very prominent as a game. However, the fact that it is not original in itself compared to the actual banner saga game, and the fact that no one is able to play the game, as there is no one to play against in this multiplayer only game, makes this game a little less than promising. I would not waste time on this until the developers work on the game to increase popularity, through advertising or working on the game's content, of which it is lacking, if at all.

Rating: 2/10

Overall Review:

        Pros:

                -Interesting Gameplay / Potential


        Cons:

                -Not original in any way

                -Very small playerbase for a multiplayer game

                -Gets boring if you have any luck finding matches | -

Warframe is a game that rewards you for the amount of time that you invest into it. If you wish for a surface level horde shooter with fun abilities then it will give you that experience in spades, however, it also has the ability to allow you to delve deeper into its systems and lets you customize and maximize your arsenal until you become a walking army.

The story is serviceable in the beginning but in my opinion ages like wine as you progress through the star chart, slowly pulling you into an experience that I have yet to relive in any other Sci-Fi game I've played. While it does go off the rails at times it does so in a way that feels believable and maintains a sense of internal consistency that keeps you informed while still asking questions.

Each frame feels unique even though the devs have released over 50 differing characters, each with a unique kit that (while falling into a manageable amount of categories such as caster vs weapons-platform) still allows players to express their own uniqueness through their selection of frames and weapons. It is rare that any two players' loadouts will be identical to one another.

It is definitely a game I recommend everyone to play at least once and one I definitely recommend to anyone who loves long grinds, deep (though sometimes confusing) mechanical systems, and extreme horde shooters. | Better Destiny

Genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
Reviews:
Path of Exile (POE) n√£o √© um MMORPG, como a maioria o classifica. POE √©, na verdade, um action-RPG online. Voc√™ n√£o tem necessariamente que interagir com outros jogadores se n√£o o quiser, e mesmo que o queira, sua intera√ß√£o √© limitada apenas a um chat global e a alguns poucos (5) jogadores que voc√™, por ventura, permita que entrem em sua equipe (party).

Considerado o sucessor verdadeiro do Diablo II pelos mais saudosistas, Path of Exile √© um jogo bastante interessante para quem gosta de RPGs hack-and-slash com uma grande gama de possibilidades em suas builds. Com uma √°rvore de habilidades de mais de 1300 pontos diferentes al√©m de um complexo sistema de crafting, cada personagem torna-se √∫nico em seu potencial, apesar de, no momento, n√£o ter tantas possibilidades de customiza√ß√£o visual.

Ap√≥s mais de 4000 horas jogadas, sinto-me confiante que posso dar o verdadeiro valor ao jogo nessa an√°lise sem, no entanto, deixar de considerar seus pontos fracos. Por isso, vamos por partes:

[h1]Conceito e Exist√™ncia[/h1]
Path of Exile √© um jogo que foi desenvolvido desde seu in√≠cio para dar aos saudosistas jogadores de Diablo II um ar de renova√ß√£o. Chris Wilson, o l√≠der do projeto, e seus companheiros fundaram uma empresa chamada Grinding Gear Games, a atual respons√°vel pelo gerenciamento do jogo, e decidiram dedicar-se exclusivamente ao desenvolvimento de POE.

Seguindo o modelo original de Diablo II, o Path of Exile tem point-of-view semelhante, embora com gr√°ficos melhores e atualizados para uma nova gera√ß√£o (inclusive, recentemente, recebendo suporte a DirectX 11 e algumas funcionalidades exclusivas deste), al√©m de conter o mesmo 'feeling' de grinding que tanto tornou Diablo II famoso.

[h1]Jogabilidade[/h1]
Com uma √°rvore de habilidades de mais de 1300 op√ß√µes, al√©m de 6 ra√ßas iniciais, POE tem uma jogabilidade altamente imers√≠vel e de grande liberdade aos jogadores. Ao criar um personagem, voc√™ tem uma s√©rie de quests que devem ser seguidas sob uma hist√≥ria modelo, dividida em dez atos e em duas partes. Ao finalizar a primeira parte da hist√≥ria, voc√™ parte para a segunda, com uma dificuldade maior, j√° que voc√™ recebe algumas penalidades.

Terminada a parte da hist√≥ria e com seu personagem por volta do level 60 (level 100 sendo o m√°ximo), voc√™ parte ent√£o para o conte√∫do end-game do jogo, que consiste, na maior parte do tempo, 'rodar' mapas (mais de 100 tipos diferentes) em dificuldades diferentes em busca de mais level e/ou itens raros e ajudar Zana, uma NPC, na guerra do atlas. √â a√≠ que o grinding se torna interessante para pessoas que gostam (como eu). Para as que n√£o gostam, voc√™ pode simplesmente come√ßar de novo se quiser e tentar novas e divertidas builds.

Para se ter uma ideia dos n√≠veis de grinding do jogo, estima-se que a possibilidade de dropar um dos itens mais raros do jogo (Espelho de Kalandra) seja de uma vez a cada dez anos se voc√™ jogar cerca de 4 horas por dia. √â bastante, de fato, mas seu alto valor no jogo faz com que todos sonhem com a possibilidade de tornarem-se ricos da noite pro dia.

Os servidores s√£o divididos em ligas. H√° a liga permanente softcore e a permanente hardcore. A diferen√ßa entre uma e outra consiste no fato de que, se voc√™ morrer com seu personagem na liga hardcore, ele ser√° automaticamente transferido para a liga softcore (ao contr√°rio de Diablo, onde voc√™ perde o personagem).

H√° tamb√©m as ligas tempor√°rias, normalmente lan√ßadas a cada 2 ou 3 meses. Elas oferecem um "fresh start", ou seja, um in√≠cio fresco para aqueles que n√£o querem se submeter √† inflacionada economia das ligas permanentes ou simplesmente desejam tentar se perpetuarem como ricos comerciantes ou crafters de itens nas novas ligas. Note que, ao final de cada liga, seus personagens l√° localizados, bem como o ba√∫ da sua conta, ser√£o transferidos para as ligas permanentes.

[h1]Gr√°ficos[/h1]
Al√©m do que pode se ver nas pr√≥prias imagens, Path of Exile n√£o √© um jogo que possa se dizer ser muito voltado ao desenvolvimento de belos gr√°ficos. Os gr√°ficos s√£o sim medianos, mas mant√©m-se sempre atualizados com o que h√° de moderno no mundo dos jogos. H√° cerca de um ano, como j√° mencionado, o jogo recebeu suporte a DirectX 11, al√©m de alguns efeitos especiais a mais (como o movimento responsivo de capas e asas de personagens a skills ou at√© mesmo o vento). Na mesma √©poca o jogo tamb√©m recebeu portabilidade para o Xbox.

Sua customiza√ß√£o visual tamb√©m n√£o √© muito rica (por enquanto), sendo voc√™, na maior parte do tempo, obrigado a ficar preso ao visual de seus itens e de sua ra√ßa (n√£o h√° diferen√ßa de sexos, por exemplo - se voc√™ escolher ra√ßa X onde o personagem √©, por padr√£o, feminino, ele continuar√° sendo feminino). Toda e qualquer customiza√ß√£o visual n√£o padr√£o, ou seja, que n√£o √© pr√≥prio do item que voc√™ esteja usando, √© paga. A √∫nica exce√ß√£o s√£o as recompensas fornecidas no final de cada liga. Apesar disso, no √∫ltimo ano, a GGG tem investido bastante nesse quesito, com uma not√°vel melhora.

O jogo tem aten√ß√£o exclusiva da Grinding Gear Games, sua empresa gerenciadora. Com um in√≠cio dif√≠cil de 5 funcion√°rios, ela hoje conta com mais de 150 pessoas em dedica√ß√£o exclusiva, fazendo com que seu suporte seja um dos mais efetivos que eu j√° tenha visto (enviei cerca de 10 a 15 tickets e a m√©dia de tempo para resposta deles foi de 5 minutos - √© incr√≠vel).

[h1]Comunidade[/h1]
Voc√™ pode escolher interagir com a comunidade ou n√£o. Esse √© o principal fator que faz com que Path of Exile n√£o seja, per-se, um MMORPG, onde, por defini√ß√£o, voc√™ √© obrigado a interagir com um universo de jogadores. No geral, a comunidade de Path of Exile √© bastante amig√°vel e disposta a ajudar, mas, como em todo jogo, h√° bastantes trolls e, principalmente, scammers.

O [i]scam[/i] √© legalizado no jogo desde que n√£o seja atrav√©s de transa√ß√µes da vida real (ou RMT - do ingl√™s, [i]real money trading[/i]). De acordo com o pr√≥prio Chris Wilson, a empresa tenta n√£o realizar nenhum tipo de regula√ß√£o do mercado dentro do jogo, logo cabe a cada jogador tomar conta de seus itens e analisar seu devido valor antes de se desfazer dele para outro jogador. Ainda segundo ele, no jogo, [i]'knowledge is power, and power is everything'[/i] (conhecimento √© poder, e poder √© tudo).

No come√ßo, n√£o foram poucas as vezes que fui enganado por jogadores mais experientes, comprando a pre√ßo de banana mercadorias que poderiam valer bem mais caso eu soubesse seu devido valor, por isso recomendo cautela a jogadores novatos.

[h1]Pay-to-win?[/h1]
[b]N√£o.[/b] N√£o h√° sequer um fator que possa ser considerado pay-to-win em todo o jogo. Tudo que √© adquirido por dinheiro real √© por mero conceito de embelezamento e/ou [i]status quo[/i]. O √∫nico fator que possa ser considerado pay-to-win para alguns jogadores (eu n√£o considero, no entanto) √© o fato de que, ao criar uma nova conta, voc√™ recebe gratuitamente 3 abas no ba√∫ e para adquirir mais abas voc√™ deve dispor de dinheiro real.

No entanto, √© bem comum o conceito de [i]mules[/i] no jogo, onde voc√™ cria v√°rios personagens (voc√™ pode criar mais de 20 ao todo) para guardar itens dentro de seus invent√°rios, o que n√£o faz com que seja um fator limitante aos jogadores que n√£o desejam pagar por conte√∫do dentro do jogo.

[h1]Conclus√£o[/h1]
Path of Exile √© uma obra-prima dos action-RPGs onlines. Sem d√∫vida o melhor do g√™nero, com a melhor companhia de jogos existente da atualidade em sua dire√ß√£o, mas eu, obviamente, sou suspeito a falar, j√° que "desperdicei" (e com orgulho) mais de 3000 horas da minha vida no jogo. Se voc√™ gosta de jogos com bastante [i]grinding[/i] e com uma grande gama de possibilidades de a√ß√µes, sugiro que teste Path of Exile.

[h1]Nota: 9.5/10[/h1]
Pontos positivos:
[+] Grinding complexo
[+] Grande gama de possibilidades
[+] √Årvore de habilidades com mais de 1300 op√ß√µes
[+] Ligas que oferecem um come√ßo igual a todos

Pontos negativos:
[-] Baixa gama de customiza√ß√£o visual (mas que tem melhorado no √∫ltimo ano) | Yoa so nach knapp 4k std. Spielzeit kann ich wohl mal ein Review verfassen :P.

Also muss man kein Geld ausgeben ? 
=> Jaein xD, wenn man sehr viel spielt und einem das Spiel nun wirklich gef√§llt sollte man seinen Stash(Truhe) erweitern, hier nimmt man dann mal 20‚Ç¨ in die Hand (wenn dir dieses Spiel keine 20‚Ç¨ wert ist dann lass es halt ^^), f√ºr dieses Spiel allerdings noch zu wenig bei dem was es dir bietet. 
Ich pers√∂nlich spiel das Spiel seit der closed Beta(2013) und habe zu jedem kostenlosen DLC ( ein DLC bietet ca so viel Umfang wie Diablo III insgesamt, es gibt bereits 5 DLC¬¥s) der Firma GrindingGearGames etwas Geld zukommen lassen und hab mir davon Stash Erweiterungen und Skins gekauft.

Ist es Einsteiger freundlich ? 
=> Auch hier ein Jaein, wer bereits viele Action RPG`s gezockt hat wird etwas schneller ins Spiel finden, wer keine Erfahrungen hat wird es sehr schwer haben aber gut Ding will Weile haben :P.
Also einfach Google nutzen und man wird schnell merken das die PoE Community ins gesamt nett und freundlich ist und es gibt ne menge Anf√§nger guides von gr√∂√üeren Streamern. Hier und da sollte man also bei Twitch.tv sich Builds in Action ansehen oder im Forum einen Build heraussuchen ;).
Und lasst euch nicht vom Skill Baum abschrecken, man wird diesen lieben wenn man das Spiel mehr und mehr versteht, genau dieser bietet einen unglaubliche Freiheiten seinen Charakter einzigartig zu machen und evtl. einen wirklich guten Build zu erstellen.

Ist es auf deutsch spielbar ?
=> JA!!!!, es ist nun m√∂glich es auf DEUTSCH zu stellen !!!!! ;-)  

Diablo III oder POE ?
=> Ich spiele beides, aber PoE bietet sag ich mal 10x so viel und ist F2P , auch grafisch mag ich PoE mehr da es d√ºsterer, brutaler und gnadenloser ist.

Gibt es einen Harcore Modus ?
=> Ja, der gestorbene Charakter landet in Sofcore. Anders als in Diablo III gibt es keine passive F√§higkeit die dich retten kann.

Ist die Story gut erz√§hlt ?
=>Nein, keine tollen Videos und auch kaum Vertonung, der Fokus lag wie es richtig ist, auf dem Gameplay, aber mitlerweile wird mehr und mehr vertont und nachgebessert.

Gibt es ein Late-Game ?
=> Ja und zwar ein absolut geaniales Late-Game !, mit lvl 60 ist man ca. fertig mit der Story welche man 3mal durchpielt (Normal,Cruel,Merciless), nach einiger Erfahrung geht das ziemlich schnell. Im Late-Game l√§uft man Maps welche durch Portale ge√∂ffnet werden und zuf√§llig generiert werden, der Name der Map gibt einem Info dar√ºber wie das Layout ca aussehen wird und welcher Boss auf einem wartet, auch hier die PoE wiki nutzen oder Ytube Videos schauen wie der Boss Fight ablaufen wird.

Gibt es einen Trade Markt wo Spieler untereinander handeln ?
=> JA, es gibt kein Gold oder √§hnliches, im Spiel findet man Orbs welche zu Iteam craften genutzt werden k√∂nnen oder auch als W√§hrung, dabei sind diese aufgrund ihrer verschiedenen Seltenheit unterschiedlich viel Wert, am Ende ist es ehher ein tausch System, ich gebe dir ``x`` von und du gibst mir deine Armor.
 
Am Ende kann ich nur sagen das es sich hier um ein Spiel handelt, f√ºr welches man viel Zeit haben sollte, der Anfang wird sehr schwer sein da es sehr viele Meschaniken gibt, wenn du also ein Spiel suchst an dem du dich messen kannst und dich frei entwickeln kannst bist du bei PoE genau richtig.

Hier noch ein paar links zu Seiten dich euch sicher weiter helfen werden ;)

http://www.pathofexile.com/forum <--- zum Build heraus suchen unter Classes / Builds

www.twitch.tv <--- hier einfach mal Builds live in Action anschauen und evtl Leute im Chat um Hilfe bitten, wie gesagt ist der gro√üe Teil der Community sehr nett, liegt vermutlich daran das es nicht competitive ist ^^.

MfG Schlomo und viel Spa√ü beim spielen !!!! | La verdad es que era bastante reticente a probar este juego. En primer lugar, no me gustan los "free2play". Suelen acabar en "pay 2 win", comunidades t√≥xicas, DLCs sospechosamente obligatorios, y una calidad general bastante baja. Adem√°s, tengo todos los Diablo comprados, desde el I al III con todas sus expansiones. Teniendo el original, ¬øpara que jugar a un clon? 

Pues Path of Exile me ha sorprendido. 

En primer lugar, en la tienda del juego s√≥lo venden objetos cosm√©ticos, espacio de almacenamiento, y packs de soporte. Nada que afecte al desarrollo del personaje o al poder de los objetos.

En cuanto al desarrollo del personaje, el juego tiene 19 clases de partida. Pero no son clases cerradas, sino m√°s bien "zonas de inicio" que puedes desarrollar a trav√©s de un √°rbol con cientos (literalmente) de skills pasivos. 

Tiene mucho contenido, diez actos. Muchas misiones secundarias, aleatorias, y tramas paralelas (maestros, refugio, etc...). Cada cierto tiempo abren una liga, en la que todos los jugadores empiezan de cero y hay alg√∫n evento espec√≠fico.

La ambientaci√≥n del mundo es muy siniestra, a ratos realmente gore. Me gusta la historia. Gr√°ficamente no est√°n mal, aunque no est√° a la altura de Diablo. 

El sistema de juego est√° lleno de buenas ideas. Por ejemplo, no hay habilidades activas, se consiguen a trav√©s de gemas que se engarzan en el equipo. Las gemas pueden subirse de nivel, y hasta hay gemas de soporte que potencian el efecto de otras gemas. 

Hay pociones, como en Diablo 2, pero se rellenan solas cuando matas enemigos, no tienes que llevar 500 pociones en el inventario.

Sistema de crafting b√°sico y avanzado. Se pueden mejorar y alterar los objetos, reforjar estad√≠sticas, etc...

En resumen, un ARPG hardcore, con una curva de aprendizaje un poco bestia al principio, pero con much√≠simas posibilidades. Encima gratis y sin pay2win. No s√© que m√°s se puede pedir. | 
[h1]Seja bem-vindo, exilado![/h1]


Path of Exile √© um RPG de a√ß√£o 3D publicado pela Grinding Gear Games. Semelhante a jogos como Diablo e Torchlight, Path of Exile permite aos jogadores explorar v√°rios calabou√ßos (dungeons) nas formas de hist√≥ria "Atos". Os jogadores t√™m uma grande variedade de classes iniciais para escolher, mas cada classe serve apenas como o ponto de partida inicial para a progress√£o do personagem de um jogador.

Os jogadores t√™m a sua disponibilidade uma enorme quantidade de gemas (skill gems) e op√ß√µes passivas da skill tree. As gemas podem ser encaixadas no equipamento do personagem e concedem uma escala larga das habilidades, que dependem do tipo e da cor da gema. As gemas podem at√© subir de n√≠vel para fornecer uma vers√£o mais forte da skill. A √°rvore de habilidades √© um conjunto vasto e complexo de combina√ß√µes de skills passivas. Cada jogador pode escolher entre uma enorme variedade de aloca√ß√µes pontuais para realmente personalizar a sua classe de personagens.

Path of Exile apresenta tanto PvE e PvP com eventos como corridas de nivelamento que ocorrem em servidores dedicados. Outras varia√ß√µes incluem um modo Cut-Throat, onde os jogadores podem invadir inst√¢ncias de outros jogadores e mat√°-los para levar seus itens. Cada evento pode durar de apenas uma hora a v√°rios meses e premiar valiosos pr√™mios para os vencedores. Os f√£s da mec√¢nica de rastreamento de dungeons (*dungeon crawling) mais tradicionais encontrados no Diablo 2 devem definitivamente dar uma chance ao Path of Exile.

*Sistema [b]dungeon crawling[/b]:

O sistema de [b]dungeon crawling[/b] √© um tipo de cen√°rio em jogos de role-playing de fantasia em que os her√≥is navegam em um ambiente labir√≠ntico, lutando contra v√°rios monstros e saqueando qualquer tesouro que possam encontrar. Devido √† sua simplicidade, o dungeon crawling pode ser mais f√°cil para um *gamemaster executar do que aventuras mais complexas, e o estilo de "hack and slash" √© apreciado por jogadores que se concentram em a√ß√£o e combate.

*Um [b]gamemaster[/b] ( GM , tamb√©m conhecido como mestre de jogo , gerente de jogo , moderador de jogo ou √°rbitro ) √© uma pessoa que atua como um organizador, oficiante para perguntas sobre regras, arbitragem para um jogo de RPG multiplayer .Eles s√£o mais comuns em jogos cooperativos em que os jogadores trabalham juntos do que em jogos competitivos em que os jogadores se op√µem uns aos outros. O ato realizado por um gamemaster √© √†s vezes referido como "Gamemastering" ou simplesmente "GM-ing".
O papel b√°sico do gamemaster √© o mesmo em quase todos os jogos tradicionais de role-playing, embora diferentes conjuntos de regras tornam os deveres espec√≠ficos do gamemaster exclusivo para esse sistema.

[b]Pr√≥s:[/b]

-Bons gr√°ficos que trabalham mesmo em PCs low-end, efeitos sonoros de alta fidelidade.
-Boa hist√≥ria
-Ambienta√ß√£o e efeitos bem elaborados, √≥timo final.
-Totalmente free to play.
-Se voc√™ decidir investir dinheiro, todos os pre√ßos est√£o bem equilibrados.
-Muitos itens
-C√≥pia fiel ao Diablo 2
-Skill tree avan√ßada 

[b]Contras:[/b]

-Alguns problemas de atraso e desconex√µes aleat√≥rias, N√£o posso dizer que √© perfeito, mas eu jogo tranquilamente com ping bem baixo. Por√©m, vejo algumas pessoas com problemas de vez em quando.
-Pontos de controle s√£o muito distantes, por esse motivo o jogador tem que correr para o objetivo com a necessidade de perder alguns minutos em vez de usar o teleporte para checkpoints, que s√£o muito longes do objetivo da miss√£o.
- Customiza√ßao de personagens.


Lendo o site ficou claro que foi produzido de f√£ para f√£s, devido a frases como:

[i] - "Totalmente gratuito e nunca ser√° pay to win"
- "Estamos cansados da moda de fadas e luzes, Path Of Exile √© real√≠stico e escuro"[/i]

Path Of Exile est√° de parab√©ns e merece respeito j√° por isto, recomendo para jogadores ass√≠duos e que veneram o estilo Old School.

Released in 2013 by Irrational Games, it builds upon the success of its predecessors while delivering a fresh, yet familiar experience. Set in the floating city of Columbia, the game introduces players to Booker DeWitt, a man tasked with rescuing a mysterious girl named Elizabeth. As the story unfolds, players are thrust into a world of political intrigue, social unrest, and philosophical exploration, with themes ranging from American exceptionalism to the nature of reality itself.

One of the standout features of "BioShock Infinite" is its narrative complexity. The plot takes unexpected twists, keeping players on their toes as they navigate the layers of conspiracy and mystery. Booker and Elizabeth‚Äôs relationship evolves in a compelling way, and their dynamic drives much of the emotional weight of the story. Elizabeth herself is a unique character, not only because of her abilities‚Äîsuch as opening "tears" in space-time‚Äîbut also because of her depth and growth throughout the game. The bond between Booker and Elizabeth becomes central to the experience, and the way the game unfolds keeps the player invested in their journey.

The world of Columbia is incredibly well-crafted, with vibrant, meticulously detailed environments that stand in stark contrast to the darker themes of the game. The floating city feels like a living, breathing entity, with its own history, culture, and class divides. The design of Columbia, from its patriotic aesthetic to its underlying dystopian nature, provides a striking commentary on American society and the consequences of unchecked nationalism. The game's use of music, especially the incorporation of old-timey renditions of modern songs, further enhances the atmosphere and immersion.

Gameplay-wise, "BioShock Infinite" is engaging and intense. The shooting mechanics are fluid, and the introduction of the Skyhook, which allows players to move across railways in the air, adds a unique verticality to the combat. The combination of gunplay, strategic use of Vigors (special powers), and Elizabeth‚Äôs ability to open tears creates a dynamic combat system that requires both quick reflexes and tactical thinking. The game encourages exploration, rewarding players with lore, upgrades, and narrative elements that deepen the story.

However, it‚Äôs not just the gameplay and world-building that make "BioShock Infinite" stand out; it‚Äôs also the philosophical depth. The game delves into complex topics like free will, the multiverse theory, and the nature of identity. It challenges players to think critically about the choices they make in the game and how those choices relate to broader existential questions. The ending, in particular, leaves a lasting impact, providing both a satisfying conclusion and a thought-provoking meditation on fate and the consequences of one‚Äôs actions.

"BioShock Infinite" is a masterpiece that blends excellent gameplay with a deep, engaging story. Its themes of freedom, oppression, and the complexity of human nature are explored in a way that feels both personal and universal. The game‚Äôs vibrant world, memorable characters, and intricate narrative make it one of the most thought-provoking and visually stunning games of its generation. While it may not appeal to every player, those who appreciate a game that challenges both the mind and the skills will find "BioShock Infinite" to be an unforgettable experience.

Eu tamb√©m tive alguns problemas com bugs de c√¢mera ou n√£o conseguir avan√ßar ap√≥s matar algum boss. Foi uma boa experi√™ncia, mas eu n√£o recomendaria para qualquer um. | Sadly not as nuanced as I hoped it would be. The beginning was so strong with the heart-string-pulling commercial about Sensen, and escaping the jail. But after that, the game slowly started to get less deep and not talk about the crazy/messed up stuff you do, and instead focus more on getting your memories back and saving the world (like every other game out there). I would have loved for the focus to be on how insane it is to mess with someones memories, and whether or not the ends you go to justify the means. After all. we're literally called an Errorist, just short one letter of a controversial term in today's society!! Luckily the twist ending satisfied me just enough, but the journey to get there was a chore. The combat is quite clunky for me, but it's combo creation mechanics are an interesting idea, and would be cool to see in other Capcom titles like Devil May Cry (maybe Street Fighter, but I don't think people would be happy), or better implemented in a sequel. Despite my gripes, I'd still recommend this game to others, as it stars a solid female lead, which is always awesome to see, and it has a nice ensemble of fairly well voice acted characters.

It is turn based and linear; you go out on missions, then return to your home to level up, re-supply, pick up side missions, and progress the story.

At first I was disappointed, but the story and atmosphere sucked me in.

Their are 5 races (Human, Elf, Dwarf, Orc, and Troll) and 6 classes (Samurai, Mage, Decker, Rigger, Shaman, Physical Adept) but racial limits on attributes and skills are disappointingly limited. There's no point in making a troll as anything other than a Samurai or Physical Adept, for example, as their racial limits would prevent any other class' skills rising above 6 points (out of 15)

The games also have fan-made campaigns available in the Steam community

If you're looking specifically for cyberpunk games then it's a must have; if you want anything else it's hit and miss.

[b]–í—ñ–¥–º—ñ–Ω–Ω–∏–π –ø—Ä–µ–¥—Å—Ç–∞–≤–Ω–∏–∫ –∂–∞–Ω—Ä—É![/b] | Fun Fact: This game actually coined the term "Roguelite", to describe Roguelike elements while not actually fitting into the mold of the genre, which is actually a set of rules determined by Roguelike developers of yore in an event called the "Berlin Convention". This game is most-assuredly not an actual Roguelike, which is why "Rogue-LITE" is used in the marketing material, because it was a brand new term and style of game at the time.

Most games people call "Roguelikes" don't actually meet the real criteria, and this has been a source of annoyance for actual Roguelike fans like me for over a decade, since the Roguelite boom, which this game is partially responsible for along with Binding of Isaac. I like Roguelites a lot, this isn't a slight against the genre, but people SERIOUSLY need to distinguish them better.

If you want to know what a real Roguelike looks like, the Genesis game Fatal Labyrinth, the Game Gear version Dragon Crystal, Nethack, Caves of Qud, Angband, Path of Achra, Cataclysm Dark Days Ahead, Quasimorph, Tales of the Maj'Eyal, ADOM, why yes I did just skim Sseth's channel to remember half of these names.

What these games all have in common, are grid-based maps, being turn based, permadeath, zero progression between runs, ("metaprogression" being out of run progression), a strong focus on being non-modal. meaning every action you can do is always available, peaceful options rarely exist, procedurally generated levels make up most of the game, and "emergent gameplay" is prioritized, meaning you have a ton of out-of-the-box options that are all generally accounted for in normal gameplay.

I actually grew up with the 3DS VC version of Dragon Crystal and the PS3 Genesis disc that had Fatal Labyrinth on it. Although, gonna be honest, I played more Dragon Crystal, and when I was playing the PS3 Genesis disc, I was playing Shinobi 3 and Streets of Rage 2, a true classic. That reminds me though, the stellar Phantasy Star 1-4 was also on that disc, and also, the PS2 Shinobi reboot and it's sequel Nightshade are actually peak, despite getting sub-par reviews for the time. Time was very kind to those games despite their insane difficulty, and I don't think I'll have another opportunity to mention those games unless Sega puts them on Steam or something.

Less faithful to the original criteria, but still great examples are the Pokemon Mystery Dungeon games, the other Mystery Dungeon spinoffs, and also Shiren The Wanderer by the same team, which has 2 releases on Steam. Also another strange example of a Roguelike is FF X-2 Last Mission, a pack-in on the HD releases of FF X+X-2, in case getting the previously PAL/JP-only vastly superior re-release version of FF X with 14 extra bosses and a better, much more open, Sphere Grid wasn't enough of a bonus.

Rogue Legacy is a very good Roguelite, and it still holds up. As you can see by my playtime, this game was a staple for me in high school, and I still come back to this game and it's sequel. The "Neo" fights in this game are entirely unbalanced, but otherwise this game is very, very good. The Donation Box was a new feature to make the "Neo" fights less crushing, and it does help a lot, but the big problem is a lot of the Neo fights require playing against your play-style. The equivalents in the sequel are much better, since instead of having set strategies you're required to learn, it's a test of how well you can clear them as each class.

Class dichotomy is also not as good in this game as in it's sequel, and the disabilities provide no compensation like in the sequel. Rogue Legacy 2 is definitely a better game, but that doesn't mean this game is BAD. After all, the sequel came out 7 years later, and hindsight is 20/20. For a while, this was one of the best 2D Roguelites out there, before we got Dead Cells, which I played extremely late, and this game still has plenty of really good ideas, even if it has some design flaws.

A lot of those design flaws really don't become apparent until you've already beaten the game and are on NG+++, so in that regard, Cellar Door succeeded at making a sufficiently well-designed game. Also, as a bonus, Cellar Door included a copy of a fan-made overhaul mod, Lament of Zors, to the game, with permission, as an alternative launch option, and that fan-made mod is very interesting and adds a lot of new areas to the game, and rebalances a lot.

In short, the sequel is a better game, but this is still a great game to come back to, even with the sequel existing. I recommend this game wholeheartedly. I know half the text here ended up talking about other games, and the distinction between Roguelite and Roguelike, but there's not really too much to say about this game itself other than that it's a well-designed action platformer responsible for the Roguelite boom. | Mon temps de jeu parle de lui-m√™me.

 | El mejor juego en mi experiencia, me encanta la atm√≥sfera, las mec√°nicas (muy simples), que no sea lineal se nota que es un juego hecho con mucho esfuerzo y dedicaci√≥n | Tremendo juegazo! He sufrido intentando pasarme la run patriotica sin amonestaciones, pero ha servido.
Gloria a Arstotzka!

A decent game, but with some pretty frustrating flaws.

Permadeath is super annoying in a co-op. Losing all your progress and then playing through the exact same dungeon again is super demotivating. We tried playing with infinite lives, but then it trivialized the game -- there was no penalty at all for death.

Also, the fact that every player controls every menu simultaneously led to a let of misclicks. My partner opened a vendor while I was attacking things, and my button press bought something for them. Worse, later they paused the game while I was attacking things, and my button press quit the game. There wasn't even an "are you sure?" dialog, it just immediately quit and we lost everything. This tipped it into thumbs down for me. | es ist ein tolles spiel das mich meine ganze Kindheit begleitet hat ich rate euch das Spiel zu kaufen !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! | Amazing modern version of gauntlet, love the pixel art and crt filters | A campanha principal √© um dos melhores Dungeon Crawleres que eu j√° joguei, s√≥ que depois que saiu o Heroes deu pra ver que a mec√¢nica √© bem limitada. Ainda sim, recomendo jogar com os amiguinhos, tem suporte pra campanhas custom e √© divertido | Pros 

Graphics and music 

Cons
Pretty much everything else, gameplay is way too repetitive, not a big fan of the controls, I could see this game being more fun coop, but probably still wouldnt add enough enjoyment to play through

Your character VERY quickly learns some pretty overpowering abilities that make combat pleasantly entertaining rather than particularly challenging (at normal difficulty). There are also lots of fun and creative weapons to experiment with. I first played this when it was relatively new, and found it just as enjoyable to come back to years later.

Some of the humor is definitely cringey and tiresome, and the main character can be rather annoying (such as shouting every time you pick up a data cluster). But if you enjoy open worlds, irreverent humor and seeing your character get stronger, it has quite a lot to offer. Just don't expect a remotely serious story. What you CAN expect is FUN.

While I may have 9 hours on Steam at the time of writing this, I had a lot more time on my console, so I can understand what I'm saying. 

The best way to experience this game is by playing with friends. The thrill of trying to survive against each other in a wide variety of maps with some optional modes is unforgettable, I still giggle whenever I think about some of the moments that I've had in this game with friends.

Quick Play can be pretty harsh, mostly everyone there has already developed the best techniques to gain high speeds in milliseconds so I did not have the best time in that mode, but I have found a few casual players every now and then that were fun to fight against.

The Campaign can be pretty thrilling to play. While yes, I was racing against bots, it managed to be pretty intense every time with Unfair mode. I go back to it sometimes, which I can't say for most of the games that I love in my library.

Basically, the best way to play this game is by playing with friends, Quick Play can often be hell, and the Campaign is very thrilling even if you are playing against bots. –ò–≥—Ä–∞ –∏–∑ –≤—Å–µ–ª–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–π SteamWorld, —Å—é–∂–µ—Ç –Ω–µ–ø–ª–æ—Ö–æ–π, –≥–µ–π–º–ø–ª–µ–π —Ö–æ—Ä–æ—à–∏–π, –¥–ª—è —Ç–µ—Ö –∫—Ç–æ –ª—é–±–∏—Ç –∫–æ–ø–∞—Ç—å, –º–æ–≥—É –æ—Ç–º–µ—Ç–∏—Ç—å –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–Ω—ã–µ –∞—á–∏–≤–∫–∏, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–µ –≤–æ—Å–ø—Ä–∏–Ω–∏–º–∞—é—Ç—Å—è –∫–∞–∫ —á–µ–ª–ª–µ–Ω–¥–∂–∏, –µ—Å—Ç—å 2 —á–∞—Å—Ç—å | I did one full playthrough that entailed mining pretty much every ore on the map, and I got every upgrade. I also got most of the achievements, excluding ones that would require another playthrough. Overall, it was pretty fun. I enjoyed it straight the way through. At first it started a bit slow, but by the end you have so many upgrades and abilities that you can just mess around with that it makes up for the slow start. I will say, earlier on, when you don't have all of the abilities, some traversal and combat feels a bit awkward and clunky, but I suppose that is a part of a lot of metroidvanias to a certain extent. 

Steamworld Dig really reminded me of a flash game called Mega Miner (all time goat of the genre by the way). I am not sure if this game was inspired by that or if it was the other way around or if they have no connection at all, but it felt insanely similar. I will say that I definitely prefer Mega Miner, and for most of the game I was just thinking "Man, I wish I was playing Mega Miner right now." That isn't a knock to this game necessarily, I just have a lot of nostalgia for Mega Miner, and I think that it had executed so many things perfectly (the main thing I prefered from Mega Miner over Steamworld Dig was the traversal). All that said, for a game I got on sale for $.89, it was totally worth the time and money, and I'm sure I will get around to playing the sequel sometime soon. 

The game does a good job of constantly giving you a new upgrade or ability to mess around with, and pretty much all of them were fun to use. The caves/mini-dungeons were also fun side challenges that hid some secrets for bonus rewards. I never felt myself really getting frustrated with the game, as even dying just means losing a bit of money and starting back up at the surface. You can still go back and claim your loot too.

There isn't much to say about the story, it is pretty basic, but they do set up for the sequel at the end of the game, so that had me a bit more interested in the story. 

I'd give this game a solid 6.5/10, it is a great starting point, and I am interested to see how the next game expands on it. | This game has been a lot of fun I enjoyed the exploration, the enemies, characters, the mining and all sorts this has been a really fun game worth playing if you love Metroidvanias. | Juegazo, en unas 4 horas te lo pasas tranquilamente, si quieres platinar ahi ya te vas a tardar, por otro lado, buena historia | La idea de excavar y mejorar al personaje es interesante, pero la ejecuci√≥n se siente demasiado limitada. No poder cavar en todas direcciones hace que la exploraci√≥n sea menos fluida de lo que me gustar√≠a, y la falta de enemigos o desaf√≠os constantes hace que el juego se vuelva mon√≥tono r√°pidamente. Despu√©s de un rato, simplemente no me apetece seguir jug√°ndolo.

When you‚Äôve managed to create an unexpectedly great first entry for a franchise, it begs the question: What the hell do you do with the sequel? In the case of Borderlands 2 developer Gearbox has decided to largely stick with what worked the first time around, while implementing a host of tweaks that make it an overall superior game. A few relatively minor complaints aside, Borderlands 2 improves not only the narrative, but almost every major game system. If you‚Äôve been itching for a reason to jump back into the world of Pandora, Borderlands 2 provides a more than ample supply.The hook of Borderlands 2, the very reason that I found myself thinking about it when I worked or tried to fall asleep, is the loot. Guns, ammo, character skins, grenade mods, class mods -- there‚Äôs always something just a bit better, something you so desperately didn‚Äôt even know you needed until you found it in Borderlands 2. Just like Diablo or a number of other action RPGs, the hunt for loot becomes intoxicating because of the tiny rush you get each time a rare colored item spills out of a chest or is dropped by a recently slain enemy. Every firefight and intense boss battle becomes all the more rewarding, because, though you might die a few times and want to crush something near you in real life, it suddenly feels like everything is going to be OK when you‚Äôre blasting away enemies with a newly looted gun. | s√≥ tem gente perturbada, armas, viol√™ncia, animais perigosos, uma milicia que quer controlar tudo, nenhum policial √° vista e um ambiente in√≥spito a vida humana.

The early aspects I found quite enjoyable, moving around the board, facing encounters, and getting stronger. Two aspects of this game just killed it for me: PVP and the end game. Essentially, I see no real reason to do anything but a strength character. Craft lets you get around a little easier at times, but strength can just steamroll everything, and if a caster has to PVP a strength character, they lose. The end game is nothing but luck. I spent nine rounds on the crown, and only twice did the command spell work. By then, two other strength players had reached me, and even with decent strength, it couldn't compete with those who had strength in double digits. Mas, al√©m de tudo, gostaria de enaltecer a arte caracter√≠stica e virtuosa, que transmite perfeitamente a atmosfera obscura das dungeons, da sofr√™ncia e do medo. - E se voc√™ for um mutante, jogue na mais dif√≠cil mesmo, √© uma experi√™ncia semelhante a estar em um quarto branco com camisa de for√ßa no corpo | This is a game I played on an off for years, and both loved it and grew frustrated by it as I played.  This last year I decided it was time to beat the game finally, so I dedicated a bit more of my gaming time to it, and feel I can give some fairly informed thoughts on the game.  

Darkest Dungeon has a fun party management system that is well designed and the heart and soul of the game.  Do you select your ranged skills for your Highwayman so he can be in position 3?  Or do you take his pos 1/2 skills and play more of a high risk high reward style of play up front?  Do you put your jester in the back making him a buffing character?  Or do you put him further forward so you can apply bleed and be more of a DPS character?  It allows you to make a lot of different parties in different ways, and as you play you learn what combo's works best for each situation, and which ones you prefer to play.  

The enemies also have positions that work differently for each enemy type, and some of your characters will let you manipulate the positions of your enemies to mess them up or put them in a position for one of your other characters to pummel them into the dirt.   So overall the game play is EXCELLENT.

Where I had my struggles with the game was losing characters.  When I first started playing the game it really hurt to lose that Leper that I had been using effectively for so many dives into the dungeon.  I eventually learned that dying is an important aspect of the game, and if you upgrade your stagecoach you will be just fine.  The death of the characters also adds weight to your decisions in the game.  If you decide to get too crazy with a party/skill composition there is a very real chance you are going to lose some of your characters.  So if you decide to play Darkest dungeon just accept right off the bat that death is part of the grim dark theme of the game.

The other aspect of the game that people may not like is the tone and atmosphere of the game.  It is a grim dark themed horror game.  Horror is not really my jam to be honest, but the game play and how the theme is executed, and the great narration of the game drew me in despite my lack of interest in the horror genre.  

Overall the game play is excellent, and the setting, style and art of the game is unique and intriguing.  I would highly recommend this to people looking for a great rogue like dungeon crawler that stands out in an over crowded market. | –£–∂–∞—Å–Ω—ã–π –¥–∏–∑–±–∞–ª–∞–Ω—Å, –ø—Ä–æ–∫–∞—á–∏–≤–∞–µ—à—å –æ–¥–Ω–æ–≥–æ –ø–µ—Ä—Å–∞ –ø–æ –º–∞–∫—Å–∏–º—É–º—É, –≤—Å–µ –¥–µ–Ω—å–≥–∏ —Å–ª–∏–≤–∞–µ—à—å –Ω–∞ —Ç–æ —á—Ç–æ–±—ã –≤—ã–ª–µ—á–∏—Ç—å –µ–≥–æ –≥—Ä—ë–±–∞–Ω—ã–π —Å–∏—Ñ–∏–ª–∏—Å, –æ—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç—å –µ–≥–æ –≤ –±–∞—Ä —Å–Ω—è—Ç—å —Å—Ç—Ä–µ—Å—Å, –ø—Ä–æ–∫–∞—á–∞—Ç—å –µ–º—É –µ–≥–æ –±–æ–µ–≤–æ–π –Ω–∞–≤—ã–∫, –∞ –æ–Ω —É–º–∏—Ä–∞–µ—Ç –Ω–∞ –æ—á–µ—Ä–µ–¥–Ω–æ–π –≤—ã–ª–∞–∑–∫–µ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–æ –∏–∑-–∑–∞ —Ç–æ–≥–æ —á—Ç–æ –∫—Ç–æ-—Ç–æ –∏–∑ –∞–≤–∞–Ω—Ç—é—Ä–∏—Å—Ç–æ–≤ —Å–æ—à—ë–ª —Å —É–º–∞ –∏ –¥–æ–±–∏–ª —Ç–≤–æ–π —Ç–∞–Ω–∫ –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–π –±—ã–ª –Ω–∞ –ª–æ–ª—Ö–ø –ø–æ—Ç–æ–º—É —á—Ç–æ —Ç–∞–∫–∞—è –∂–µ –æ–±–µ–∑—É–º–µ–≤—à–∞—è –≤–µ—Å—Ç–∞–ª–∫–∞ –æ—Ç–∫–∞–∑–∞–ª–∞—Å—å –µ–≥–æ –ª–µ—á–∏—Ç—å. –ù—É –≤ –æ–±—â–µ–º –æ–±–æ–∂–∞—é —ç—Ç—É –∏–≥—Ä—É, –Ω–µ —Å–º–æ—Ç—Ä—è –Ω–∞ –≤–µ—á–Ω—É—é –±–æ–º–±—ë–∂–∫—É –º–Ω–µ —ç—Ç–æ –∑–∞—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç.

A lot of games that are heavily based around systems and emergent gameplay fall somewhat flat for me because doing things in wacky ways feels somewhat pointless beyond "lol you can just drop a big rock on the enemies" or whatever.

Heat Signature is a case of a game in which the standard stuff that you get shown in the tutorial is and lots of fun by itself (it's hotline miami by way of FTL) but the act of exploiting the game's systems is also both intuitive and wildly effective. The game really clicks when you get on a big ship to assassinate someone, see the 40 people with shields between you and them, and decide instead to go hijack a different ship alltogether to shoot some holes into the former so you can dock right next to your target. Despite the relatively simplistic designs of the procedurally generated ships, there's tons of variety from mission to mission, and I keep discovering new things despite the fact that the game doesn't actually unlock much and progression is just new mission types or getting to buy certain item types instead of having to find them.

Anyway, it's lots of fun, you should play it. | It's good as far as what you get from it. The game progresses by getting more high end gadgets that let you take on enemies who will be invincible otherwise. You can generally classic stealth to a point but enemy contractors will make you play more seat of your pants. There's a few types of missions, and the enjoyment of the game is from going in to a hard mission and trying to win.

Balancing your inventory between weapons and gadgets is part of the game. You pick up a lot of stuff and you need to use it to win.

Understand that this is not a progression quest, the end game isn't that great and if you aren't enjoying it you should stop playing. The actual payoff is the defector missions where you get a bit of cool equipment and try to do a hard mission. i.e, the reward for playing the game is playing the game. | Un exellent jeu au gameplay tr√®s riche permettant tout type d'approches aux missions. J'y reviens encore des ann√©es plus tard tant le jeu est prenant | i VERY much like this game, its just lots of fun, even going for high scores is very fun, its about tricks and strategy timing it is easier tho (with that slowmo) | Fav of mine, if you're at all interested in immersive sim or stealth games and want to see a weird spin on that check it out.

I came back to this game after not playing for many years because of fond memories of the unique mechanics and the strategy.  I cant think of another game quite like this. 

I really enjoyed the problem solving, and scenario planning aspect of the game.  It is a ton of fun to play, once you figure it out, and this is where this game falls down, in guiding new players.  

I would highly recommend new players to not shun character guides and other online resources to get going.  This is a ten year old game and I think they purposefully designed the game around "discovery" mechanics (especially around character skill progression and item effects) so you learn by doing,  Which I think would be fine if you unlocked something that documented the information for you so if you step away for a few weeks you don't forget.  I find myself wasting resources to "find out" what something does only to have forgotten even later in the play through. 

Personally I think if this game underwent a UX/UI cleanup, slightly better tutorialization of some of the mechanics and better information persistance you could re-release this game today and it would attract a huge following. | Addictive, good looking, funny, rogue type game that makes you utilize brain and try it in different play modes.
