But in its current state, I cannot recommend it. The game is plagued with exploits and, worst of all‚Äîcheaters.

[h2]But hey, you can just report them, right? Sure! You just need to follow these SIMPLE steps:[/h2]

[list]
[*]Pre-record all your gameplay or use an instant replay feature (Don't have a high-end PC? Too bad!)
[*]Manually gather evidence and put together a solid report.
[*]Submit the report through a long, outdated browser-based process with strict criteria (such as capturing the cheater's nametag‚Äîwhich is much harder than it sounds).
[*]Deal with ridiculous limitations‚Äîonly five evidence files per report, each under 50MB. If your files are too big, you‚Äôll need to upload them elsewhere.
[/list]

Easy peasy, right? And even if you do all that and receive confirmation that the cheater was banned, it's just a minor inconvenience for them. Why? Because of ban evasion. Without going into too much detail, they can simply create a new account in under five minutes‚Äîwithout even repurchasing the game.

[h2]But I still like the game. Can I give feedback, suggest solutions, or discuss the cheater problem with the community?[/h2]

Whoa, whoa! Easy there, champ. Turns out, that‚Äôs not allowed either. Apparently, players are only supposed to report cheaters and trust that the devs are ‚Äúworking on it.‚Äù But hey, give them time‚Äîit‚Äôs not like this game has been out for over five years, right? üòÉ

Here‚Äôs part of a response from a staff member on the official Sea of Thieves forums:

"[...] Dropping anchor here as while we know this comes from a good place and of wanting to make the game better, and we do as well, the forums is not the space to discuss solutions when it comes to these things. This is because only the internal team know of what is and isn't possible and it is not something that is easily solved or has a quick solution. [...]"

[h2]To summarize:[/h2]

Reporting a single cheater takes far too much time. And if we consider the time a player loses at the hands of a cheater, let‚Äôs not forget:

[list]
[*]You could lose a boat full of treasure (representing two or more hours of gameplay).
[*]You could lose an Hourglass streak that took several hours to build.
[*]And now, on top of that, you‚Äôre expected to waste more of your time filing a detailed report‚Äîa job that shouldn‚Äôt be yours in the first place.
[/list]

[h2]To be fair...[/h2]

They do fix exploits‚Äîeventually.
But if you don‚Äôt mind a game infested with cheaters, go ahead‚Äîit‚Äôs a great game.

And the other 3 games (Quiplash 3, Champ'd Up, and Talking POints) are EXTREMELY fun. Of the party packs i own, this is def my fav | Really great pack. I recommend you get it on sale however. | Where do I start. Champd up is an amazing game, absolutely love and recommend it, I don't think I've met someone who didn't enjoy that game. Quiplash, also a solid addition to the pack, although just a remake, and although this is an unpopular opinion, I really do enjoy the devils and the details. I think its a creative game and while it could have been executed better, provides a one of a kind experience. Altogether, this is a great pack and I recommend it | I'll rate the games individually based on how fun they are to play in a party [P] setting (friends/family in person) and on like a discord [D] stream (computers, virtual)

Champ'd Up - [P 4/5, D 6/5 (this game rocks)]
Quiplash 3 - [P 5/5, D 4/5]
Devils and the Details - [P 2/5, D 2/5]
Talking Points - [P 5/5, D 3/5]
Blather Round - [P 3/5, D 3/5]

Overall this pack is really good, I'd say it's worth | Oh hey, my profile picture is one of the devils from The Devils and the Details. Either way...

Tl;dr of my mini-reviews of each game: This pack is still very solid, even though with some games there are small "ughs".

---------------

Quiplash 3: Aesthetically one of the more unique ones of the Jackbox series, featuring claymation-style elements. Quiplash is Quiplash, you fill in the blanks of sentences and make a ha-ha. The only caveat I have with this version is the music - in the soundtrack it's fine, but during gameplay, it's intimidating even... but it's easily brushed off.

The Devils and the Details: Hhhhhhhh - mixed feelings. It's a group game where some tasks are independent, some require teamwork. You fill a bar with the tasks you do and move to the next day. Here, it really depends on the group of people you are playing with - playing with people other than those that you have vocal contact with is borderline impossible, just because of the teamwork-required tasks. Even then, this is something I occasionally play with a group of people and get joy out of it. Occasionally = far less than the other games, but still played.

Champ'd Up: To this day, still probably the best drawing game in Jackbox Packs. You draw characters based on a prompt, and then get a rival whose appearance you see, but don't know the prompt. Then they fight each other. It's so simple in concept, but really fun. Also, bonus points to the music - Andy Poland went hard and I appreciate it, really digging the electronic music mixed with march band drums. Kinda reminds me of Death Grips' earlier works through that.

Talking Points: Vocal improvisation, the game - speaking is mandatory in this game, and so, should be played with those with vocal contact. You get a topic for a slideshow, but don't know the pictures that a different player chooses for you. This game usually gets extremely restless and out-of-bounds, which can be really fun at times. Freeplay-mode for this is an odd choice.

Blather 'Round: This game is one of my go-to games when introducing Jackbox to other players (others being Tee K.O. and Guesspionage). You get a thing that you have to explain about with using cryptic words, and give "praise/discipline" to player-given answers (in other words, you can agree, or don't agree with a word to lead others onward). Fun and engaging, best with a big player group. This game should've gotten the Freeplay-mode, but I guess such wasn't picked up for the potential difficulty of giving custom words the prompts that the game gives you?

While I appreciate the character DLCs, I don't really like the direction this game has taken for replayability. Having seasonal mechanics tacked on seems like the easy approach but doesn't add much to the overall game. They really should take the Dead Cells model with the stage scheming and add more branching zones and tilesets to make things feel fresh. Add more variety to the rooms per stage, like with the recent anxi desert change. Stick to one overarching mechanic that players can keep grinding on instead of adding seasonal ones that shift character useability and run approach every 4 months.

Subsequent updates also seem to be introducing some lag to the game. Tabbing out, even in singleplayer makes the game hang for a split second. Entering one room in multiplayer after someone else causes the game to hang at times. If the devs really do want to stick to the seasonal plan, then expand the skins to include the characters as well and make them limited to events! Soul essence is already a persistent currency that players can acquire with a grind. | I've sunk a few hundred hours into this game; once you grasp the connections between guns, abilities, and scrolls, it becomes  seriously addicting. I've played every season variation, and the way star link expands upon your character build is the most fun yet. I can easily justify $20 due to the amount of content it offers. | There's only two solid FPS Roguelites at this point... and this is one of them. (Other is roboqquest).

Build diversity is good, weapons are fun to use. Its just to have something you can quickly pick up and start shooting, nothing much to really think about. | I didn't give this game much thought until I started playing it. The game is a well-made rogue-lite that's fun to play. The experience is even better with friends, up to three people, or you can find online matches.
I've highlighted 3 points that I think are important to mention:

Seasons
The season system is well-made. I've only played the last 2 seasons. At first, it's hard to understand the mechanics, but you get the hang of it over time. You just have to pay close attention to the readings, but they're very fun and varied. The season pass is free, easy and quick to get, and gives you beautiful and well-made cosmetics, which is a very positive point.

Replayability
I particularly enjoyed replaying the game. Putting on a playlist to listen to while playing is a pleasant experience. The game has many achievements and some of them require time and effort to complete, a huge variety of weapons to unlock, which gives a great feeling when you get a new weapon, in days when in any game you have to keep paying to get new things in the game (the game has 3 DLC with weapons, but the game also adds free weapons in each season).

Game modes
The game has few modes, only three, being the conventional mode, the main game mode where you have the stages and their difficulty to choose and challenge yourself and it is in this mode that you unlock most of the weapons and achievements in the game. The daily challenge mode, nothing special, the name already says what it is, a mode with a modifier that changes daily, just to get some achievements and challenge yourself. And the last mode, the horde mode, is a mode where you can equip some improvements to your characters and fight against large hordes of enemies that get harder and harder over time, but it has a final boss, so the hordes end. It's fun, but it only has two maps so far, and it ends up being repetitive.

My final thoughts are that the game is worth it for those who like games of this style, it's very different and diverse from the others. For the base game I think the price is worth it, but for the DLC I think it's worth waiting for a sale.

As someone with hundreds of hours in StS and thousands in Monster Train, this game is awesome.

The art is beautiful, the enemies are varied and interesting. The emergent narrative and the overarching goal of the game makes me come back to it again and again.

Some inexperience shows here and there, with cards "borrowed" from StS, but the game has SO MUCH besides it, to the point where I see these cards as an homage, rather than plagiarism. 

If you like deck building, I can't recommend this game enough | If you're a fan of Slay the Spire / Monster Train, or any other variation of those types of games, this game is similar enough to where you might get some enjoyment out of it. Off the rip, the game is extremely fun (at first) as you're exploring different areas and learning the mechanics of the game but the more you play the game you realize it's less of a roguelike and more of a linear progression (meta) type game. 

In games like this you'd want to explore different deck synergies, go to different parts of the map, etc to find new ways of winning but at the end of the day there are mechanics in this game that pigeon hold you if you want to beat the final boss. For example, on the run that I'm on with one of the three main characters, I have to defeat this NPC towards the final part of the run FOUR times before he'll reveal to me how I can beat the final boss. ... That's about 4 grinding hours worth of game play just to unlock a mechanic needed to beat the boss... The more that I played this game the more apparent it became that there's not enough theory crafting with items and decks and it's more about linear progression. 

Other reviewers summed it up perfectly, this game has an "Illusion of choice" where you think it's diverse with its roguelike mechanics but it's lacking in that department. If you like story-rich RPGs, this game offers an interesting, unique take on the genre where it's blending deck building roguelikes with RPGs. However, if you're a seasoned vet of StS/Monster Train and are looking for something to satisfy that itch until StS2 comes out, this may or may not be the game for you. 

 | Dialogue towards the end is indicative of more content but that content isn't there. Game is good for what it is, but I was disappointed to hear Mortis talking about the future and then see that the game was basically over for that character. | Great if you like StS and Wildfrost.  It's RPG themed with lots of backstory and character development.  The map path is again like StS but has a lot of secrets and unlocks.  The difficult is highly variable and so are the strategies.  It has a lot of content and replayability. It's also being actively developed so there should be more future content and the devs actually address bugs. | Ce jeu est une r√©ussite. Je me suis demand√© si il n'√©tait pas un peu cher pour un deckbuilder et au final j'y ai trouv√© plus de contenu que ce √† quoi je m'attendais. Je n'ai pour l'instant jou√© que les 3 versions du personnage "Perceval" (reste deux autres personnages), et je n'ai m√™me pas encore fini la campagne, car la progression n'est pas lin√©aire. Il y a du d√©fi, le gameplay est classique, les combos sont nombreux, aucune partie ne se ressemble. J'ai bien aim√© la narration, sans d√©voiler trop, je peux dire que c'est original. Je pense √† ce dialogue plein d'humour : "Tu t'es suicid√© ?" ... "Oui c'est moins douloureux que de combattre Millenis". C'est un bon game dans le style Slay the spire, √† savoir que vous contr√¥lez des personnages mod√©lis√©s et anim√©s. En conclusion si vous n'aimez pas les jeux de cartes "free to play" magnifiques, mais qui vous co√ªtent une blinde pour finir par copier le deck ultime que tout le monde joue (au moins jusqu'√† la prochaine extension dans 3 jours) ... Si vous n'aimez pas non plus ces jeux beaux et courts (steamworld Hand of Gilgamesh) , ou mal √©quilibr√©s, trop simplistes (Vault of the void), voir √©nervants (Darkest Dungeon) ... Knock on the coffin est le jeu qui vous offrira suffisament de profondeur pour lui pardonner ses quelques faiblesses.

The only reason I am giving thumbs down is to balance with the positive reviews, it's not a "very positive" worthy game, to me... Consider this a neutral from me.

It's an average escape room/puzzle game with a couple of very unreasonable "puzzles" and a rather clunky interface.

If nothing else, this is the best board to digital game I have ever played. The soundtrack and sound design is impactful and charming. The animations are also tantalizing to look at. This is an awesome deck building/area control game which rewards you the more you play. The spirits( a total of 24 and I have only played 6) are all wonderfully diverse with their own play styles. It's hard to pick an absolute favorite but if I had to choose a tie then it would be between Shadows and Thunder Bearer. 

I've never played the board game before this digital adaptation and the last time I tried one (Small World), it was completely underwhelming. 
This is exactly what every board to digital conversion needs to be. Awesome work by the dev team!
 | They have done a very good job recreating the game. The graphics are nice and the automation makes playing easy. There are a few bugs but by in large, very solid game. | Amazing game 
Very practical to play and easy to play fast compare to tabletop 

Only downside is that it takes 2 months to release a New spirit | I've always loved the board game, and the digital version lets me both play with distant friends and to practice by myself without spending 75% of my life on set up. Once you get used to the interface (which can be slightly un-intuitive), it is just as amazing as the board game (which for the record is thee best board game I have played).

Things to note:
Jagged Earth is not yet complete, still missing Memory, Trickster and Starlight, but as far as I understand, those will be being released fairly soon. Promo pack 2 and Nature incarnate are also yet to be available. Extremely fun, a very noticeable and expanded improvement over the previous installment (which was a very enjoyable game on its own). Ironed out the difficulty curve and new game plus experience pretty nicely
There might be some minor balance issues here and there, but with the vast amount of classes, combinations and progression.... it is to be expected
I was addicted from the start and right to reaching the true end, extremely high replay value | I have played a lot of Roguelikes, and I think Rogue Legacy 2 is genuinely my favorite of them all. Maybe not the best of them; There's pretty limited build variety beyond class and weapon choice, the end game is pretty lack-luster, run variety isn't that wild either.

But.

It is stuffed to the brim in charm and heart and humor. It feels like home in that sense. I can just pick the game up and play and never have a bad time. The gameplay is so smooth it puts most pure metroidvanias to shame. The classes are ALL fun. All of them. All bangers. The soundtrack is fantastic. The artstyle is cute and charming while also maintaining its own identity. There could definitely be more modifiers and more classes and more zones and more bosses, but I think that's the best flaw a game can have, no? To just want *more* of it. 

10/10. Maybe not the perfect roguevania, but for my money its my favorite. | This game is one of the best rougelikes out there and worth buying at full price. This is a really solid game and it really fills the light management niche quite nicely. 

It's fun to play around in if you like designing and the requirements for all the different types of rooms and spaces in the school vary enough to keep things interesting. It manages to offer a little challenge for those who like adapting on the fly while still being engaging enough for those that like to tear everything down and rebuild in a more organized, modular fashion.

As opposed to Oxygen Not Included, the game doesn't require you to delve into the management of pipes and material transport systems (which was my least favorite part of ONI). There's basic farming and production limits and storage but that's about the extent of it. You can quickly craft little zombie bots to do a lot of your hauling for you which frees up your teachers and students to teach and learn and dance in a circle around an enchantophone.

Staff and student scheduling is simple, though the grouping system is still a bit wonky. I also get the feeling that the devs intend that the 'best' way to play is to churn through your students and staff. Graduating and Retiring your staff is incentivised through the reward of relics which are used to upgrade subsequent students/staff, so if you are one of those players that gets attached to your characters you're going to be making the game more difficult for yourself.

Overall I think this is an easy recommend. The developers have done a great job on the skeleton of the game, so depending on your options chosen it can play as a challenging, resource-scarce, base survival game, a light magic-themed school/base designer game, or anywhere in between. | a cool twist on a rimworld/oxygen not included formula.

low skill floor, high skill ceiling. keyword system keeps things fresh and interesting without the need to forever explore and expand. pawn stat randomisation and relics give something to chase for. events and difficulty are highly customizable, providing a range of challenge options.

a very easy recommend. | Mind Over Magic is just great. I play it pretty much since it hit Early Access. One of the best Colony Sims there is. I can wholeheartedly recommend it. | Build your own school for young mages! This is a 2D simulation with many twists over other simulations.

It has exploration, lots of building (with arbitrary rooms and sizes), mage sims who work on the schedules you enter, smart groups for scheduling or tasks where you can create criteria and even new students will be automatically selected, RPG stats and skills, and turn-based old-school tactical magic combat. Although it's 2D, it has much of the creativity of a 3D building game. It will feel familiar to anyone who plays the genre of sims, but has some very unique gameplay elements.

You start at the site of an ancient school of magic destroyed by a curse, and your three starting professors (with the help of the founder's ghost) must recruit and train young mages to eventually become professors, to help lift the curse. The more students you train and graduate, the bigger your school can be, and the more potent the school becomes.

There are tons of secrets to find, unusual plants and materials to harvest, powerful relics to find and create, wands to upgrade, and deadly traps and events to handle.

I found this game quite entertaining, and am a fan of other Klei games such as Oxygen Not Included. This is not as complex as ONI, but has much of the charm and excitement of discovery through exploration. Unlike most RPGs like this, you are expected to graduate students and let them depart forever. Losing a mage may take a little time to replace, but everyone is replaceable. | I was playing this from the earliest versions, enjoying the game and hoping for it to become more with each regular update. The game went through a lot of changes until 1.0 (current version at the time of review), the devs listened to feedback and it turned out good, actually really fun. Its similar to ONI but less polished and with lesser freedom to how to solve problems, which are centerpiece of the game - you need x and for that you need y, z and c, but c requires a and d, or you could do just f and g, up to you. An ultimate indie magic base building fantasy is what I would call this game, a fair warning, a huge part of the game is base building (which is hugely predetermined at the start of the game by the seed), lesser part is focused on actual school management, and fights still need polish not to be repetitive. Also, on higher difficulties you will need excel tables to do well. I would recommend trying it if youre into this kind of games and/or watch a good deal of gameplay.

Overview: Tomb Raider (2013) is a reboot of the classic action-adventure franchise, offering a fresh origin story for the legendary adventurer Lara Croft. Developed by Crystal Dynamics, the game takes a more grounded and gritty approach to Lara's character, portraying her transformation from a vulnerable young woman into the hardened explorer she's known for. Combining exploration, puzzle-solving, and intense combat, the 2013 iteration offers a blend of action and survival mechanics set on the mysterious island of Yamatai.

Story: The story follows Lara Croft, who, along with her crew, becomes stranded on the island of Yamatai while searching for the lost kingdom of Himiko. The island, however, is home to many dark secrets, including a dangerous cult and other perils that put Lara‚Äôs life in constant jeopardy. Throughout the game, Lara faces various challenges and fights to survive, all while uncovering the island‚Äôs mysteries and discovering her own strength.

The narrative is engaging, focusing on Lara's personal journey and her development as a character. The story touches on themes of survival, trust, and the cost of discovery, with the stakes rising as Lara delves deeper into the island‚Äôs secrets. The characters are well-developed, though the focus is primarily on Lara, making her transformation and growth the heart of the plot.

Gameplay: Tomb Raider (2013) brings a mix of exploration, platforming, puzzle-solving, and combat. The controls are smooth and accessible, with an emphasis on both exploration and action. As Lara navigates the island, players engage in intense combat against various enemies, including mercenaries, wild animals, and the island‚Äôs cultists. The combat system is robust, offering a variety of weapons, from bow and arrows to firearms, as well as a range of stealth and melee attacks.

The game also features light RPG elements, allowing players to upgrade Lara‚Äôs weapons and abilities as they progress. This adds a layer of depth to the gameplay, encouraging players to explore the island thoroughly to collect resources and improve their equipment. There are also collectible items and hidden treasures scattered throughout the game, rewarding those who take the time to explore off the beaten path.

Graphics and Performance: The graphics in Tomb Raider (2013) are exceptional, with lush environments, stunning character models, and impressive lighting effects. The island of Yamatai is beautifully designed, ranging from treacherous cliffs to dense jungles, all rendered in high detail. The character animations, particularly Lara‚Äôs, are lifelike, and the facial expressions convey emotion and intensity. The cinematic cutscenes are integrated seamlessly into the gameplay, making the narrative feel fluid and immersive.

The game runs smoothly on most modern systems, with well-optimized performance. On higher settings, the visuals are breathtaking, but even at lower settings, the game still maintains a high level of quality.

Audio Design: The audio design in Tomb Raider is excellent, with a haunting and atmospheric soundtrack that complements the game‚Äôs tone. The sound effects are realistic, from the sounds of Lara‚Äôs footsteps on different surfaces to the crackling of fire and distant roars of danger. The voice acting, particularly from Camilla Luddington as Lara Croft, is solid, adding depth to the character‚Äôs emotions as she faces peril after peril.

Challenges: While the game is generally well-balanced, some sections can feel a bit repetitive, especially in terms of combat. Some of the puzzles are relatively simple, and while they provide a nice break from the action, they don‚Äôt challenge players too much. The difficulty ramps up during some of the more intense sequences, especially during the combat-heavy portions, but overall, the game provides an enjoyable experience without being overwhelmingly difficult.

Final Thoughts: Tomb Raider (2013) successfully reinvents the franchise, offering a modern and more personal take on Lara Croft‚Äôs origin story. The game blends action, exploration, and survival mechanics into a thrilling adventure, with a great narrative that makes you care about Lara‚Äôs journey. Its visuals, gameplay mechanics, and immersive world design make it a standout entry in the action-adventure genre.

Pros:

Engaging story with strong character development
Beautiful graphics and immersive world design
Satisfying combat mechanics with a variety of weapons
Excellent audio and voice acting
Exploration and collectibles add depth to gameplay
Cons:

Combat can become repetitive
Some puzzles are relatively easy

Tomb Raider (2013) is a fantastic reboot that blends classic Tomb Raider elements with modern gameplay features. I bought my copy tonight and played the tutorial and a full game against the AI. I think there are some opportunities for DAISU but overall the gameplay itself is solid.

Opportunities:
- Tiles could be clearer on zoom in. I like that the text is there, but I want to explore the art on those tiles too. I want a button to do a big zoom like I can do on Tabletop Simulator or Tabletopia.
- The tutorial has text that cannot be sped up and it doesn't always fit in the text bubble. That needs to be a) easily skippable and b) fit in the text bubble. I know you need to read the text, but you shouldn't be guessing how fast I can read. I can read much faster than the "next" text arrow appears.
- Play Local has New Game and Tutorial buttons that appear to be greyed out, but they aren't. And you're supposed to click them.
- When playing with AI, you can't see what your partner drew/chose for use in your castle, so you can't synergize with them. This led to me making decisions for my castle in a vacuum.
- I finished the second tutorial, but it never acknowledged I finished it. It just wouldn't accept feedback anymore and I had to hit escape and 'exit' to go back to the menu.
- Music sometimes behaves odd. Leaving the tutorial to the main menu made the music abruptly stop and then go to a new music track. Perhaps a fade out and fade in would be less jarring.
- The green "Ok" or select button is an odd design choice, it doesn't feel like it matches the same aesthetic of the rest of the game, but I find myself punching the spacebar to accept my changes anyway. It's not a real big deal.

All of that said, I really enjoyed my time with BTCoMKL. The beta was ROUGH on my PC, it was very choppy, very jerky, this has been completely resolved. It runs so quick and it says all settings are on Epic despite me not having a gaming laptop at all. It's a cheap Dell my father-in-law bought that I put a SSD in.
Everything I love about BTCoMKL is still here in the PC version except for the plotting and planning with my partner. BUT it did feel significantly better to crap on one of my castles to try and take the lead from the AI who had the lead.

I like how quick the gameplay was. It was a delight. I hope the online lobby picks up. I think the price for the game was fair too. Of course I always find myself wanting to wait for a Steam sale but I'm not much of a PC gamer, so I typically have no problem waiting. That said, I don't regret not waiting. Congratulations Team Daisu.

Oh, one more item of delight I wanted to mention.. I love how adding tiles to the castle actually causes the castle to grow behind you. You see walls come up and towers rise. It's a very neat effect that made me smile a couple of times. Also, great job identifying the castles by color. That made it very easy to identify which castle I was working with. | Actually, the only way I would play this game is through this app: unlike the board game, this digital version permanently displays your and your opponents' score throughout the entire game.  In the board game you had no idea how well you or your opponents are doing, except until the very end.  This digital version totally solves that.  I own the physical game, but I will provably almost never play it again, unless one of my friends desperately requests it. And finally, the interface of this (digital) game and the overall design is done near-perfectly. I had a lot of fun playing this game on my steamdeck while traveling but I will 100% say this game feels kind of unfinished and poorly balanced. A lot of my enjoyment was derived from trying to figure out how to win on the harder difficulties with each character in spite of the poor balancing. 

It's definitely a neat concept that I havent seen done before and I enjoyed discovering neat combinations of tiles on the map like Village + Vampire Manor = Vampire Town. But I wish there was more of that. There should be dozens and dozens of combinations and interactions, but there's really not. It feels like there's content waiting to be implemented but it just never came. 

It's got some soft "gambling" elements in that you can end runs early to cash in your treasure or you can always go for another loop or attempt a boss in an all-or-nothing kind of way.  | Loop Hero is a game with an interesting concept that unfortunately falls flat due to its repetitive gameplay, lack of depth, and grind-heavy mechanics. While it initially hooks you with its unique premise, the novelty quickly wears off, leaving behind a tedious experience that struggles to hold your attention.

The gameplay loop, while innovative at first, quickly becomes monotonous. You‚Äôre essentially watching your hero walk in circles, placing tiles and hoping RNG works in your favor. While there‚Äôs some strategy involved in how you build the map, it doesn‚Äôt take long for the game to feel more like an idle clicker than a true roguelike or strategy game. The lack of direct control over your character makes the experience feel passive and unengaging.

Progression is painfully slow. The grind to gather resources and unlock upgrades drags on for far too long, and it often feels like the game is artificially padding its length. This grind-heavy structure completely saps the sense of accomplishment and makes every new run feel more like a chore than an exciting challenge.

The story and world-building are minimal, which is disappointing given the game's intriguing aesthetic. While the pixel art is charming and the music is atmospheric, these elements aren‚Äôt enough to compensate for the lack of compelling narrative or character development.

Loop Hero is a game that could have been great but falls short due to its repetitive gameplay, shallow mechanics, and grind-heavy progression. While it might appeal to players who enjoy idle games or background distractions, it‚Äôs hard to recommend for anyone looking for a more engaging or strategic experience.

Rating: 4/10 ‚Äì A loop you‚Äôll want to break out of. | La verdad es que este juego lo llevo jugando desde que salio, sin embargo lo jugaba pirateado en vieja pc, en cuanto mejore con respecto a pc lo primero que compre fue este juego y no eh parado de jugarlo.

Cube Escape Collection is a collection of 9 games connected to the Rusty Lake series which I started a while back but never got to sit down and finish them. My first entry into the Rusty Lake series was Hotel, and thinking back on it, I really wish I had started with this game first. playing this makes the series make a lot more sense even if it's just a little bit with specific parts. 

the game itself is a point-and-click puzzle game, horror game, and mystery game, and personally, I think it does all of its jobs well. That being said, there were some puzzles where I was like, Man, what? or How the hell was I supposed to figure that out? But that issue slowly faded as I continued playing. I actually started to get accustomed to how they design puzzles and began really enjoying them. 

While there were times I got stuck for long periods (The Cave, I‚Äôm looking at you, screw that last section, lmfao), I never got so frustrated that I hated the game. In fact, it was the quite the opposite I actually felt mentally rewarded after solving the puzzles. That, combined with a solid episodic story, made the experience even better. The story is very confusing, like you really have to pay close attention, if you don't there's so much you'll end up missing with the story. hell there's so much I thought I missed even WHILE paying attention. so the game kind of forces your full energy. I honestly recommend before playing "birthday" and "theater" in this set of games to play Rusty Lake: Hotel and before you play "The Cave" to play "Roots" as it helps a lot with understanding everything in the story. I feel like without those games you will definitely sit there with the biggest eye brow raise. 

The closest game I can compare this vibe to is the Zero Escape series, though Cube Escape is definitely much goofier than anything in Zero Escape. | Rusty Lake is a series that confuses the heck out of me, but I still find myself drawn back to it time and time again. The Cube Escape Collection‚Äîa bundle of nine flash games from 2015 to 2018‚Äîbrought together the origins of the overarching story that now spans multiple games. I originally started with Hotel, as while they do have a chronological order, they obviously don‚Äôt need to be played in that order.
I enjoyed it a lot, no surprise there, with the many WTF moments. Despite hitting some roadblocks where I couldn't figure what to do without a guide (difficulty tended to be all over the place), it was a great set of games to just jump into and have a quick session. In my opinion, peak puzzle gaming. | I have known this series since I was a child, I love all of these games, they are my childhood and it tis nice to experience them once more. Very good games, they have a very cool and dark atmosphere, kind of David Lynch like. I defenitlely recommend this game, even if you don't like puzzler games. | Still rhe best puzzle game ever, i have all the games from rusty lake and deserve to buy it and play it | Sem d√∫vidas, a franquia [b]Cube Escape[/b] √© a minha favorita desde quando eu era pequeno. Quando encontrei essas obras de arte no Armor Games, devorei todos e me apaixonei pelo universo e pela hist√≥ria [i]completamente bizarra[/i], mas muito bem conectada entre dos jogos. Foi incr√≠velmente satisfat√≥rio fazer esse 100% sem consultar os v√≠deos de passo a passo a cada puzzle como eu fazia antigamente!

Genres: Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
Reviews: I've played Runescape way back since 2005, before Runescape 2 and 3. There's always a part of me that yearns to play this game, no matter how old I get. The grind has become immense compared to when I first played, and the micro transactions have kept me from playing any more. Sure, there's an ironman mode you can play to avoid that for the most part, but micro transactions have still become a fundamental feature of the game itself which takes away from the grind many of us suffered in the early days, before you could basically buy experience or items from Jagex themselves. | amazing game, brings my childhood memories, a little bit the new combat is off but it is still good | fishng

This game deserves a lot more love than it has gotten. It is a very well done game and has awesome combos and mechanics. I'm surprised this doesn't have more attention similar to other games like Wildfrost. it is super fun and great at the lower difficulties, but as you move up to Legend there are far fewer strategies that work consistently. You can always high roll, but the lack of resources make a lot of synergies and combos difficult to pull off. Then you have manacast Druid spam that almost trivializes any difficulty, which is quite a jarring disparity. Curious to see if they will eventually release a "imperial collect" bundle for $300+ just like CK II. | TL;DR: Base game at $10 is cool to play with your friends. Full price game/extra content isn't worth it


This game is good. Not great. Not Fantastic. Not bold or new or genre-defining.
It's a 'good' game that's gotten worse since being bought by Paradox for one poignant reason:
Their pricing is outrageous. Saying this is a $20 game is a stretch but I'll bite;
But the DLCs are not worth $5 per hero and $10/$20 for 'campaign expansions'.
There is a good reason why purchases are low and reviews are mixed for those items.
Paradox is gross for trying to monetize this game like Stellaris. | I don't recommend playing this game.

It is too fun. It is too addictive and every battle is pure novelty. It's endlessly playable and I just dropped 150+ in like....a month into this game. My sleep is completely messed up. 10/10 would get addicted again. | Êú¨‰ΩìÁÆóÊòØ‰∏çÈîôÁöÑÊ∏∏ÊàèÔºåÊÉ≥Áé©ÁöÑËØùÂª∫ËÆÆÂú®ÊâìÊäòÊó∂‰π∞Êú¨‰ΩìÁé©Áé©Â∞±Ë°å‰∫ÜÔºådlcÊÄß‰ª∑ÊØîÊûÅ‰ΩéÔºåËøôÂà∂‰ΩúÁªÑÂêÉÁõ∏ÁúüÊòØÈöæÁúã | Game was fantastic at launch, but then they teamed up with Paradox as a publisher which lead to the addition of a scummy unnecessary data-mining Paradox launcher (and a new EULA allowing data collection from your computer must be agreed to in order to play the game) and a huge flurry of miniscule overpriced DLCs. Absolutely not.

Honestly, at the price it's at, there's not much to lose if you're looking for an interesting challenge. The concept is great and so is the design, but it lacks tutorial and is overall pretty finicky. Majority of the time spent playing is wasted on running away from skeletons or constantly redirecting the people to actually go through with the action you give them. At some point, it gets so tiring and stressful to constantly have to set new paths just so that the little guys can avoid a tiny obstacle. Especially when it comes to hunting, it's just so impossible for the code to actually follow through without constantly losing track of the deer. I get that's the point, but with skeletons being so overpowered and having the ability to walk through fences, it leaves little to no room for actual progression if there is a constant need for intervention with every task. | This game feels almost...Unfinished. I understand the model the company is going for with the "one game released every two weeks", but it leads to not the best experience when playing the games.

Pyramida has no tutorial at all, and no way to figure out the commands of the game; there's nothing in it explaining how to start playing, and I had to come back to the discussion board to see if anyone else had the same problem (the answer is yes lol). There's also no pause button, a stylistic choice per the developer - however, the dev said you can just quit the game whenever you want to pause. If you can quit the game to pause, what difference does it make to not have a pause button?

The game was stressful but not in a "oh, this is challenging!" way. It was stressful in a way that killed any wish I had to keep playing. | It's a cute game, simplistic art style and so forth. However, the game can glitch at times and it lacks a tutorial - it's unclear on how you're supposed to play. Once you understand how, it's quite easy to pick up though. Regardless of this, can't fault the price of it. | theres a 30 fps cap, but it is still enjoyable to play. The NPCs are a bit fidgetty to mess with, but you can manage it, if, you're patient enough. Not long, completed in 3rd run after 4 hours, some achivement still left, maybe later (which means "probably not ever doing")

Game Name: SEGA Mega Drive and Genesis Classics
Reviews:
Good emulator, terrible decision to delist it to bump up sonic sales | For its time, I found it a fair exchange to legally purchase ROMs without any BS. Unfortunately there's not as much money in that compared to repackaging them or putting them behind a subscription service.

I respect the original concept but not the decision of delisting it to avoid competing with yourself. A similar sentiment towards the also delisted Dreamcast Collection. | Realmente queria jugar varios juegos de sega genesis en esta coleccion. Compre este juego en un pack hace mucho, pero lamentablemente, no lo instale cuando lo compre. Y ahora a la fecha del 2025, resulta que ni aunque tenga el juego en mi libreria, me sirve poder acceder a la biblioteca completa de los juegos de Genesis. 
Al menos en la Switch pude comprar la coleccion y esos juegos se mantendran. Pero en mi Steam Deck, la biblioteca que aparece en la interfaz del juego es desalentadora, solo 2 juegos DLC aparecen. Una perdida de tiempo total. | Of course they delisted it! That's what SEGA does. They make a compilation but only one press of it, then they make a new version for the next consoles but it's worse. Then they put the games on Steam and remove them because they're working on ANOTHER compilation, this time with an atrocious UI, and later remove that as well. Mark my words, Switch 2 is coming out for way more money than reasonable and SEGA mentioned wanting to revive some of their popular franchises, two of which have since been made better by other companies, two of which were tried previously and came out awful - they're not making AAA revisits of the greats, they're making WayForward vibe games for $40 each and will pump out another compilation. I want to be wrong and say they're gonna give us gold but it's SEGA. Trust me, I want this to age very poorly but, c'mon, we care about them more than they do about themselves. | I bought this ‚Äúcollection ‚Äú before it was pulled from the store. Once I DL it and opened it there was only one game in the collection. Golden Axe. Am I missing something? I thought it had more than 50 games in this like the others.

Not sure why one the most popular tags for this game is "Relaxing", the game is actually stressful af 

The sheer anxiety that I get from thinking that there maybe was a better spot for this tile, I just couldn't find it. The absolute terror of watching the number of avaliable tiles slowly go down and realising that there's almost nothing you can do to replenish them. The anger that builds up inside me when I think: "No, not the fields tile again! Where the hell do I put it?!"

[h1]ÊúÄÂêéÔºåÁ•ùÂ§ßÂÆ∂ÁöÑÁ≥ØÁ±≥Êó©Êó•Âπ≤ÁøªÂ§ßÁü≥Â§¥ÔºåËææÊàêÁü≥Â§¥Ëá™Áî±„ÄÇ[/h1] | (the) Gnorp Apologue is a clicker/idle game hybrid.

I will start this review by mentioning that this game is not a set-and-forget type of game! You will need at most 5 minutes or 10 minutes periods of AFKing at some point, but this game is VERY active and engaging. The game only lasts between 10 and 30 hours (depending on how well you understand the synergies of the talents) and how active you are.

The art style, animations, music, story even the tooltips are all superb. This is one of the few games that really deserves it 'Overwhelmingly Positive' reviews. It was fun from start to finish, getting the achievements required some good thinking and due to it's shorter length than average, you are constantly finding new mechanics, buildings, talents, synergies, etc... until the very end of the game! Now obviously you can continue playing beyond that, but as it is, I don't believe it has enough content for that. Myco (Myco), please? :D

Overall, a masterpiece as far as clicker/idle games go!

First thing, this game is very very addictive, I'd give you that. Once you start a game you will find it very very hard to stop playing. My 227 hours play time should be evidence enough to prove my point. But sadly, among my 227 play time, 99% of it was solo play. I would dearly like to join a clan and play with some other players. But alas, although the game does support clan play, some feature of the game or should I say lack of it, made it very unfriendly for clan play.  

The one thing I hate about this game is that all members within a clan shares everything. And in everything, I mean freaking EVERYTHING. All you can do is to trust in your clan member's ethics and hope they won't rob you blind when you're not in the game. Even the stuff in your so-call personal strongbox can be access by your clan members. So what good is a personal strongbox if everyone can get the stuff you stashed in it. I mean, why put in a personal strongbox in the first place is its utterly useless. At least put in some permission settings for the owner to restrict access to their stuff. 

Another thing is the loot system. I once cleared a tier 2 rift boss when another player came in and took all my loot dropped from the boss. The player was not even a clan member, just another solo player who came in and ninja looted all my stuff. 

All of this BS is making it very hard for anyone to form and invite people into a clan unless all the clan members are also real life friends. No one likes to be betrayed and rob of their hard earn possessions when they are not looking.

But, after mentioning all the bad stuff, I'm still gonna recommend this to others. A Little to the Left offers multiple solution levels and an option to skip some levels which really helps out at points. The puzzles are fun to complete, but some of them are slightly bugged. Items need to 'click' in their spots so sometimes you might find yourself stuck on a level just because the spoon was off it's designated location by half a pixel. The game also offers daily tasks. If achievements aren't important to you I'd say that the Seeing Stars DLC is not worth to get, the puzzles are not as good as the other ones. Overall, A Little to the Left is a cozy and relaxing game, a little overpriced, but definitely worth it with a discount. 8.5/10 (0.5 for the cute cat).

Alina of the Arena is an awesome game. I never tried a deck builder like it before, but can‚Äôt stop playing. I first started expecting not much but with every run I learned more about mechanics, enemies, tactics etc. and still have not tried out or learned everything. Only downside is that I would like to have more‚Ä¶ maybe a part two will happen in the future? I hope so!

I don‚Äôt want to get in much details but just be aware that this game is not only a deck builder but also a rogue like and tactics game. Give it a try if you are interested.

To make the start a bit easier let me give you some advice, but be aware of spoilers:
[spoiler]- Always think ahead. Not only what cards you might play next but your positioning!
- Cards or items which let you avoid or reduce damage in any way are very powerful. This can be achieved not only by movement, but kicks, pushes, interrupts, traps, abilities, items etc. ‚Äì be creative
- Achievements or unlocking new classes can be done with all difficulties
- Classes differ in their play style. Some are better for offence, others for defence (block) or can do both well. I tried them all. Some are very fun and insanely powerful like pyromancer, hunter or mercenary. Others or more difficult to handle like samurai or deprived
- You can drink a potion after a fight without taking it in your item slot. Just click on the potion in the menu where you can replace items which were thrown into the arena and choose the option ‚Äúuse‚Äù
- You can reload ranged weapons with all combat cards if they have the correct colour even if they are defence (block) cards
- Two-handed ranged weapons can be reloaded with both red and blue combat cards
- Reloading a weapon with a combat card does not cost any action points
- Using a combat card which can only be used once per fight, is not exhausted if you use it for reloading[/spoiler] | If you like roguelike deckbuilders and tactics games, you'll probably go on a binge with this one. To be honest, there's nothing groundbreaking about the few new things this game adds to combat based deckbuilders, it's just that Alina of the Arena tramples over every mark outstandingly. | ÂæàÂ•ΩÁé©ÁöÑÈÅäÊà≤

this is the largest disparity i've ever experienced between how a game looks and how it plays | ÂàùËßÅÁîªÈù¢ÂÉè‰∏Ä‰∏™È°µÊ∏∏ÔºåÁúüÊ≠£Áé©ËøõÂéªÊâçÂèëÁé∞ÁªÜËäÇ‰πãÂ§ÑÁπÅÂ§öÔºåÂêÑÁßçÊÑèÂ§ñÂíåËøûÈîÅÂèçÂ∫îÔºåËøòÊúâËÆ∏Â§öÂ§ß‰Ω¨ÁöÑmodÔºåÊûÅÂ§ßÊèêÂçá‰∫ÜÂèØÁé©ÊÄßÔºåËã•È•ÆÈÜáÈÜ™,‰∏çËßâËá™ÈÜâ | ÈùûÂ∏∏Â•ΩÁöÑÈÅäÊà≤ÔºåÁæé‰∏≠‰∏çË∂≥ÁöÑÊòØÈùû‰∫∫È°ûËÉΩÂäõÂç°ÁâáÈÅ∏ÊìáËºÉÂ§öÔºåÊØîÂ¶ÇÈ£≤Êµ∑Ê∞¥„ÄÅÂ§úË¶ñÁ≠âÁõ¥Êé•Èôç‰Ωé‰∫ÜÈÅäÊà≤Èõ£Â∫¶‰πüÈôç‰Ωé‰∫ÜÈÅäÊà≤ÊåëÊà∞ÊÄß„ÄÇ | Despite how it looks, this is a very complex and punishing survival game. You go from hoarding coconuts as your only source of food to eventually farming vegetables and keeping livestock. You go from sleeping on a crappy bed of leaves and having monkeys stealing your belongings, to eventually building your own house with a shed and a nice bed. 

The mechanics constantly surprised me with how in-depth they are. You might think you hit the jackpot when you find a few banana trees but your character will start getting depressed if you force them to eat literally nothing but bananas for days. If you try to live off coconuts too much you'll get diarrhea. It's actually possible to make certain animals go extinct if you keep hunting the same kinds over and over. 

Rainfall is super important for your consistent water source but it's totally random whether it rains or not. I didn't realise this until I went over a month in one game without any rain. At first this seemed really harsh but I think it's better for gameplay as it teaches you not to rely on one source of water/food/protection etc and to constantly be thinking of ways to diversify or to prepare for emergencies. 

The only thing I struggle with in this game is repetitiveness. There are different characters or even custom characters that work slightly differently but ultimately you are still in the same jungle with the same locations and same animals and same research tree. So I'll have a lot of fun playing a game for 10~ hours then die stupidly because I lost track of time in the middle of the jungle and couldn't find my way home or something like that, but I need to wait a few months to try again otherwise it feels too same-y. I wish the dev would come out with more iterations of this game like medieval fantasy style so I can swap between them :) | Absolutely loved this game.  I failed my first couple of runs and was beginning to think I just couldn't survive!  But I prevailed with a "win" after a very long run.  My favorite part about the game? Definitely the way that even though it's "just a card game", your day to day survival really tells a story.  There were some moments in the game that will stick with me almost as if I was actually on an island trying to survive - you know, like when I had almost every status effect that you could have and was in my mud hut in the middle of the night trying to cool down and calm down but couldn't sleep because I was too hot.  Or trying to feed my befriended macaque who was slightly too hungry / unhappy so he instead bit me so I tried to feed him again so he bit me again.  Incredible!

i really like this concept and idea. if you're looking for a almost casual rpg that has plenty to do but doesn't really block you from exploring or stumbling around then this is the game for you. | A very fun game for those that enjoy a merchant game. A lot of fun quirks thrown in, side activities to make money multiple endings, and a consistent sense of progression. Especially on sale, this is a gem, but even at full price it's a lovely experience. Kudos to the Dev. | This is simply a fun game.

The humour is dumb fun, the gameplay is simple but varied, and almost everything in it is creative and interesting.

It's not a traditional shop style game. You don't haggle with customers. During the shop phases, you just restock each item into its own slot when it gets sold (until you automate it). The more interactive parts (at least early) are finding new customers, new items to sell or getting stock. Some items you need to craft, some items you need to do a scavenger hunt for, some you need to grow...

The game also has 3 distinct 'acts' that, again, are nicely varied to keep it interesting. You go from super poor, to moderately well off, to super rich, and the way you're making money and what you're doing between visits to your shop are very different between these acts.

I saw another review say it was grindy - its a shop game. Your goal is to make money, usually by selling stuff. There is obviously an element of grinding sales, but it doesn't overstay its welcome. It's like well balanced encounters in a JRPG, you don't complain about the fighting.

Took me 25 hours to complete the story which seems like it would be reasonable for most people.

Great game. Well done dev. | Got this as a random recommendation for niche games that had come out over the past couple years. It did not disappoint at all, and for only $15 bucks it offers a lot of content (I put in a couple dozen hours doing all the side content in the game before getting to the ending and I haven't even touched the roguelike mode yet). 

Main gameplay revolves around the tycoon shop keeping segments and progress in it helps you advance the main plot. This segment is at a midpoint of an incremental game and a tycoon game you'd find in roblox. Where this game really shines though is in the side content. This part felt a lot like the Yakuza games where you'd wander around the world and stumble across npcs that can offer objectives or new mechanics. This side content really made the overall world feel solid and I found myself discovering new stuff in old zones far into the game. 

I also really enjoyed the story and characters. The dialogue was often witty and most npcs end up becoming relevant in later points in the game. You'd befriend a silly npc near the start of the game and they'd end up being important towards the end of the game with a new side mission or mechanic. The themes and messaging in the game was also nice and offered a hopeful end message.

Overall, I'd highly recommend this game. | Traigan el sopapo que le hago otra hija a la protagonista

The Steamdeck compatibility warns you that external controllers don't work, but I still purchased after seeing some reviews that said they do. 

While external controllers work, expect them to randomly stop working, disconnect, swap players or have 3 seconds input delay randomly throughout the gameplay. 

It was a little painful to restart or reconnect every 20mins or so, but my partner and I managed to finish the base game with the deck docked to the TV running 1080p.

If they release an update to fix the controller input we might come back and finish some of the optional challenges. | This game is so cute and so fun! Some of the events/challenges are quite difficult and complicated but I think it's great for a Coop game to not just be easy. 
Wardrobe options are beautiful and funny. Super fun couch coop, you might get annoyed with your partner but it's worth it for the fun :) 
Highly recommend, closest excitement and thought provoking puzzles we've had since It Takes Two <3 | A cute and good game, bought it at a discount which made it VERY worth it. Definitely recommend to play with someone else since that's the main part of the game - imo it'd be too frustrating and boring playing alone. The kiwi bird customisation/skins are fun too.

It's such a shame cause beneath all the bugs, glitches and stuttering there's an amazing game with all the bells and whistles when it comes to the story, characters, atmosphere, soundtrack and gameplay.
Having only experienced the star wars universe through fallen order and now survivor, Cal's journey feels personal and epic, even without knowing the films. 
The story is much darker and longer in runtime with abundance of side content to get lost into, combat is faster and smoother with 5 stances to choose from this time around keeping it fresh! (blaster/dual wield are my go to). 
It's like the performance issues are the "dark side", Trust in the "Force" and it'll guide you through them! | its the typical ea experience meaning the game runs like ass and the ea launcher wont connect to its servers so its not even playable... i hate everything about this

Reviews: No Reviews

When I first saw this game I thought it looked ridiculous, a pointless waste of time. Nothing about it sounded fun. But then I watched a video of someone playing it on YouTube and thought it looked much more fun than the promotional videos had shown. So I gave it a try and OMG, I totally enjoyed this game. It has no right to be as fun as it is. I tend to be a completionist and this game helped scratch that itch. The best part is that I'm a huge fan of Castlevania so that DLC was just the greatest thing I never knew I needed. Seriously, for me the Castlevania DLC made the game at least 10x more fun.

My only complaint would be it's kind of a one and done for me. Once everything is collected I don't feel a need to play it. Loved playing it that first time around though, collecting all the things, unlocking all the stuff, it was fantastic. I'd have to do a complete fresh install to relock everything to make unlocking it again enjoyable. But still, it was the best 190+ hours of my recent gaming life :D | This game has the best ratio between the amount of fun you'll have with the fewest amount of buttons. I've never played anything this deep with literally just WSAD and Space. Also, 5‚Ç¨ full price for this? What a bargain. I get that it's a simple game, but come on. Give yourselves some credit, devs. And thanks for the full ultrawide support, although I would prefer a third option to solid and transparent black bars, which would be no black bars, but that's a massive nitpick.

EDIT: Ooooooh! That's how they make money! They have DLCs, so the whole game is actually 20‚Ç¨ if you want everything. That makes way more sense. Still too cheap though, because from what I've tried from the DLCs so far, they are very good and definitely worth the asking price. | A lot of people like it but I honestly found it kind of boring. Just wander around automatically shooting stuff until you get overwhelmed, then repeat. It's fine but wasn't my kind of game. | Literalmente el juego del vicio a su m√°ximo esplendor, el trailer habla por si solo, vas a dejar tu vida jugando a este juego para conseguir todos los desbloqueables y probar todas las combinaciones o personajes posibles.

El contenido que obtienes de juego por lo que pagas es totalmente justo, ya poseo todos los DLC hasta la fecha y realmente cada uno suma una cantidad de contenido absurdo que da para aun mas horas de juego.

Adem√°s, como fan de la saga Castlevania es muy divertido ir notando cada una de las referencias que guarda este juego y cuando a√±adieron el DLC de Castlevania, literalmente explote.

 | ÂâßÊÉÖÊª°ÂàÜ ÂêêÊßΩ‰∏ÄÁÇπÊúâÁöÑÂâßÊÉÖÂíåÊîØÁ∫ø‰∏çÁúãÊîªÁï•Ê≠£Â∏∏‰∫∫‰∏ÄËæàÂ≠êÈÉΩÊâæ‰∏çÂà∞ | What a nice and I would not afraid to say it is innovative game but jeez it is messy. You ever read any wuxia manhwa/manhua, they are also called murim works, well this is literaly them minus memes since it is very calssic and conservative with very righteous and benevolent characaters and it feels so natural in this setting and stunning art direction in a well executed 2,5D which just screams ancient China and you love it. A lot, and I mean a lot lot cultivation methods, techniques with different weapons, all of which are uniquely drawn and presented. And this all is just shoveled into your mouth without any filter or notice. 

Right of the bat you are given half of the map and you can go literaly everywhere, find dozens of NPC that you can rob through a friendly spar and get stronger by widening your meridians, as funny as it sounds this is what you would be doing majority of the game and you would enjoy it, but at some point there would be so much to do and remember that you would be overwhelmed and start missing content, dialogues or even quests that can hugely impact your story and gameplay. Nobody would warn you that there is some potential companion dies in random z-city because you simply never visited it or did so but at a wrong time. You would go through main quest just by going to sleep because it is written in the journal to do so, but by doing it you would miss most of the important bits that affect that same quest and rewards. 

I do know that there are games like Trails Series which change NPC dialogues after every cutscene but Wandering Sword is far and beyond that. Genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Free To Play
Reviews: No Reviews

I'm really torn on whether to actually recommend this game or not. It's a B- at best.

This game is made in Unity, which means it overheats my computer. I don't think any point-and-click should ever be made with Unity. Opening and closing the game is sluggish, and I didn't enjoy the fact that I had to slowly turn the book pages every time I wanted to get to a later level.

[b]Little Cabin in the Woods[/b]
It was going really well until I got to the end when I became severely stuck and there were zero in-game hints about anything. Clicking the "?" was getting me nowhere, so I eventually caved and went looking for the walkthrough. Turns out there was an area on the screen that I was supposed to click that is incredibly difficult to spot because it blends right in with everything else ([spoiler]seriously, that gap in the wood looked exactly the same as all the other gaps, like there was nothing about it that drew my eye to that area[/spoiler]). Very rage-inducing end to an otherwise alright experience.

[b]Portrait of an Obsession[/b]
I think it‚Äôs pretty good for what you get, but I swear there had to be at least two instances of me clicking around and nothing happening, which incorrectly told me there‚Äôs nothing there or that the object doesn‚Äôt work there. But then these areas were clickable only after the puzzle is ready to complete, meaning I was very stumped for sections of the game in places I definitely wouldn‚Äôt have been otherwise.

[b]GrandMa's Delicious Cakes[/b]
On the short side, but hit the spot with puzzles. Only downside was that the game froze on several occasions.

[b]Rise of Pico[/b]
Somehow even shorter than the GrandMa one, but it managed to be very good on the puzzles. I will, however, complain that the background music for this one was so unbearable that I had to turn it off.

[b]The Left Behind[/b]
I liked most of it, but some of the puzzles were infuriating. I really disliked the physics one that required getting the balls through the hole, and I absolutely hated the one where you had to recreate the painting by rotating the tiles. On the latter, I  had to take a step back before I rage quit, and when I returned to it, the game glitched out and decided I solved the puzzle after a few futile rotations.

Overall, the feeling I'm left with is that of a chocolate chip and shit cookie. Very difficult to separate the two. But because I can only choose between a thumbs up or down, I'm going to be lenient with the thumbs up since I did technically manage to get through the game without needing the hints... technically. | 25.1.27Ôºö

 | This game is a very fun strategy and roguelike game, i love the variety of cards for you and the enemy and the achievements have kept me playing for a bit now, definitely worth it for the price but would pick it up on a sale like I did. | This is exactly my kind of silliness. Shotgun King is a chess game except you only have your king left and he has a shotgun. If that makes you think "Wait a minute, that's not chess at all!" then you would be correct. The game only wears its chess influence only on the surface, the game actually is a turn-based strategy roguelike. You have to play through 12 rounds and defeat the final boss at the end. Each round your goal is to kill the white king. You can do this by firing your shotgun, each white piece have different amount of HP, pawns and knights have the lowest and the king has the most. Your shotgun has three main stats: firepower, range and firing arc. Firepower defines how many pellets your shotgun fires, each pellet dealing exactly one damage. Multiple pellets can hit the same target, can hit multiple targets or completely miss any target. There is some RNG involved here but the closer you stand to your target, the more likely you are to hit it. Range shows the maximum travel range of your pellets. Your firing arc shows the spread of your pellets, they will always be inside this arc. Shooting an enemy that stands directly before you will always make all pellets hit him. It's the same concept as in other shooting games, the shotgun is more powerful close range and loses its power the further you stand away. However, sometimes a wider spread might be beneficial to hit more pieces. There are some strategic decisions you can make here.
Shooting or moving will always pass your turn. White pieces will move on their turn and they can move multiple pieces at the same time. They have their own speed stat that defines how many turns they have to wait until they can move.
Moving will also reload your shotgun. This is important, so you can move outside of check and fire on your next turn.
Your shotgun has only limited ammo, which does regenerate but very slowly, so you don't want to kill every piece, you want to focus on the king but still deal with troublesome pieces.

After each floor you will come in contact with the roguelike mechanic of the game, the cards. You get a selection of two different black cards which help you for the rest of the run. These can be simple like more firepower, ammo or range but they also can give you completely new abilites like a melee attack that does not use ammo or grenades, that will hit multiple pieces but can also kill you.
Each black card is tied to a white card. These are upgrades for the white side. They can get more pieces, change how pieces move and give pieces more HP or speed. You will have to evaluate what upgrades you need but also what downsides you can endure in return. One white card that always appears is the white queen after floor 3. You can't escape her, she is everywhere.
Killing a non-pawn piece will give you an edge however. You get their "soul" which you can activate to move in the same pattern as the piece you killed. You can only store one soul but you can get black cards that allow you to store more or have some other synergy with it. These soul cards are best used to get out of check or close the distance to the white king.

The game is incredibly goofy with its concept but its also a challenging strategy game that will take you some time to master. And as you beat th egame, you will start to unlock new difficulty levels that add extra pieces at the start, improve the enemy AI and give the white king more HP. You can also unlock new shotguns that have different starting stats. There is a surprising amount of variety in this small game. The game still gets updates to this day, despite being almost three years old. It's funny, it's challening and it's the exact type of game to play at the evening after a long work day. | Fun game, nice and easy but with just the right amount of strategy involved.

The level designs, voice acting and general mechanics combined make this game an absolute treat to play. 

There's so many different difficulties, play styles and builds to choose from too, giving you the freedom of choice to either have a laid back roam through a quick map or a long and twisted rouge-like adventure. Even better, despite it being released back in 2018, it's still getting updates (including new maps)!

L‚Äôambiance sonore joue √©galement un r√¥le crucial dans l‚Äôimmersion. Les musiques, √† la fois discr√®tes et envo√ªtantes, accentuent le sentiment de myst√®re et d‚Äô√©tranget√©.

[h1]Quelques d√©fauts mineurs[/h1]
Si Underground Blossom est une r√©ussite sur de nombreux aspects, il n‚Äôest pas exempt de petits d√©fauts. De plus, bien que l‚Äôhistoire soit captivante, elle reste cryptique et pourra frustrer les joueurs en qu√™te de r√©ponses claires. Rusty Lake laisse souvent planer des zones d‚Äôombre, pr√©f√©rant sugg√©rer plut√¥t qu‚Äôexpliquer. Tolles Spiel empfehlenswert! | Once again I am in something of a quandary.  Steam insists on this 'all or none' approach to ratings and recommendations.  I wouldn't rate this as a 5, although it certainly held up for a considerable time as being a genuine prospect for 5 stars.  I played all of the Rusty Lake games in the order recommended by the developers (posted in the Cube Escape Collection Discussion).  I found the first 2/3 of the games to be engaging and challenging.  Things seemed to go pear shaped at around the Paradox stage.  I have a personal issue with that particular game because I was thwarted in playing early on because I could not complete the 'bug killing' challenge with the globe because of my arthritis. Despite several posts and emails to the developers I failed to get any response to a workaround or alternative so that I could complete the game.  That isn't what changed my view of the overall series though.  Things seemed to depart from the thread that was originally established around the White Door stage and continued on from there.  The whole rigmarole of having to jump to Discord, external web sites and social media platforms did nothing to enhance the game play and left me nonplussed.  The Samsara Room was underwhelming, the Past Within suddenly required you to have a playing partner as it was designed as a coop game - again with no apparent workaround and finally Underground Blossom seem to fall flat for me as it was nowhere near as challenging as the first 2/3 of the games.  Bottom line - if you can buy them all bundled (I got all of the games for about $20) I would say it's a good deal.  But it does seem to lose it's way and start to run out of gas (and ideas) as time wears on.  I'd give it a 3 1/2 - 4. | Another game from Rusty Lake universe. This time puzzles were less creepy and also easier (except the usual extra achievements, that are just damn hard - unless you check the Lake's community). We learn more about one of the characters that previously was mostly mysterious. So... in general for fans of the series. If you will play it separately, might be a bit weird

i have played a lot of games, for a long time. many different genres, design sensiblities, and art styles, across several decades, on so many different systems. from NetHack to Hades II, from SpaceChem to Cookie Clicker, from DOOM (1993) to DOOM (2016).

this, for my money, might be the best game ever made.

intuitively simple; exquisitely complex and deep. i have every achievement and still cannot see a future where i don't play this anymore. arguably, this video game's existence is a testament to the undying creativity of the human spirit --- that we make works of dear significance and utter perfection almost by accident simply by following those pursuits we enjoy most.

furthermore, here i am, inspired to write all this pseudopoetic drivel about a video game next to meme reviews by accounts pretending to be Goku or whatever. but i wouldn't be sitting here calling it the best game ever made if it didn't also drive me to write "the undying creativity of the human spirit" in a steam review

just buy it, and buy it again for whatever other platforms you have. it's really good | this game takes something traditional, familiar, and fundamental to the games people play and then shows why the medium of classic playing cards will be timeless forever. | Woe upon those lost souls who enter here. A good Persona game, although I find it lacking compared to P4G and P5R.
The added $35 expansion also irritating me.
 It's like... P4G has a better story/plot and characters, and P5R has better combat/gameplay/personas, as well as the best characters in the franchise.
I still enjoyed P3R, but damn.. I wish I would have started the Persona series with this one, I may have liked it more if it was my first entry into the franchise.

My experience with the Persona series in order from P4G, then P5R and finally P3R is comparable to eating a delicious prime cut medium rare steak, then eating some delicious cajun spiced king crab legs, ...and then eating a hamburger..
Like yeah, a hamburger is good and all, but it ain't no king crab legs. Feel me? | First of all, I want to say that this is an absolutely beautiful game!  After 641 hours, I have finally mastered it, unlocked all achievements.  I feel a great sense of accomplishment in being able to complete this challenging task.  Needless to say, this game is highly recommended by me.  I consider myself to be somewhat of an expert on Persona games.  I have played them all and they are all wonderful.  I actually played Persona 3 a long time ago when it was released on PS 2 but I don't really remember that much.  As for Persona 3 Reload, I can't think of anything negative to say about it.  The story and dialogue are very endearing and captivating.  I had to play through the main game 3 times because I messed up on getting all the social links the second time.  However, I did watch and read through everything.  The individual social link scenarios in this game are especially interesting.  And also, in addition to the main social links, you also have the link episodes with a few of the other characters on your team, who do not have social links.  You do these several times in order to unlock additional personas.  Also, if you engage in other activities with your characters, you find that you can get a deeper understanding of their backstory and upgrade the character's Theurgy and characteristics.  This was a nice touch and really added to the overall development of the plot.  A good portion of the playtime in this game is spent fighting battles in Tartarus.  The battle system is similar to the other Persona games.  However, in this one, you can't talk to the enemies.  You acquire personas by winning their cards in the shuffle or by fusing.  I have a completed persona compendium.  There are a few top personas that I think are the best.  For a long time, I was using only Masakado.  Then I started using Messiah when I got that.  Orpheus Telos was the last one I got and that one is also good.  The first time you play the game though, you obviously don't have these high level personas.  I was playing on the normal difficulty level and I didn't really have any trouble with the fighting.  As long as you fight all the enemies you encounter, you gain sufficient levels.  The battles are fun in this game and battle music is good.  I also like the fact that it shows you the enemies info, weaknesses and what skills they have.  This is very helpful.  There are also the requests from Elizabeth.  I have been able to complete all the requests except for the last one.  As of right now, I don't know if I can beat her.  I only tried a few times so maybe I will try again.  The requests are kind of like a side quest that don't you don't really have to do.  There are a few that will unlock personas though and I like to be as thorough as possible so I did them.  Anyway, for me, the most fun and at the same time challenging aspect of the game was trying to get all the social links.  As I said before, the second time I played the game, I messed up and I was about 5 days short, which was very depressing.  I have a very detailed spreadsheet that I wrote out what I did every day and I could see where I made my mistake but by then it was too late to fix so I had to play the whole game all over again.  I am very happy that I was able to play this game and I want to thank the developers for making it.  It's very addictive and once you start, you just want to play and not do anything else.  Even after being tired from working 8 hours every day, it gives me something to look forward to at night and on the weekends.  I hope they continue making more Persona games in the future.  I have heard rumors about a possible Persona 6 but nothing confirmed.  Please, please, please, let there be a Persona 6.  I have bought multiple copies of other Persona games and I will keep playing them and showing my support.  I'm done with Persona 3 for now.  In case you didn't know, there is also anime based on the game.  It's split into 4 parts, or 4 movies.  I watched that also.  I thought it was nice to watch because, even though in the game the main character is silent, they didn't make him like that in the movies.  He actually does have a personality and a name, which I did use when I played, the name I mean.  So, if you like Persona and Shin Megami Tensei games like me but you haven't played Persona 3 yet, give it a try.  My file is currently showing 641 hours but I may go back and do a few more things later.  I just got that Metaphor game so I'm going to play that, also by Atlus.  Bought it a few days ago.  I haven't tried it yet but it looks good.  I feel like a wrote a lot but didn't say very much.  I just love Persona. | ÊûØÁá•ÁöÑÁà¨Â°îÊàñÊòØ‰∏çÂêàÁêÜÁöÑÁ§æÁæ§ÔºåÂ§™Â§öÂ§™Â§öÊÉ≥ËØ¥ÁöÑËØùÔºåÂú®ÊúÄÂêéÈó≠‰∏äÁúºÂìçËµ∑„Ç≠„Éü„ÅÆË®òÊÜ∂Êó∂ÈÉΩÈáäÁÑ∂‰∫Ü„ÄÇ | Â§™ÊúâÁîüÊ¥ª‰∫ÜpÁ≥ªÂàóÔºåËôΩÁÑ∂Áà¨Â°îÊòØÁ≤™ÂùëËù∂Ê≥≥Ôºå‰ΩÜÂêÉËøáÂ±é‰πãÂêéÁöÑÁ≥ñÊâçÊõ¥ÁîúÔºåËøôÁôæÊù•Â∞èÊó∂‰∏ãÊù•Âà∞ÁªìÂ±ÄÁúüÁöÑÂ§™‰∏çËàç‰∫ÜÔºåPÁ≥ªÂàóÁé©‰∫ÜÁªùÂØπ‰∏ç‰∫è | –°–º–µ—Ä—Ç—å - —ç—Ç–æ –Ω–∞–≤—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞. –≠—Ç–æ–≥–æ –Ω–µ –∏–∑–º–µ–Ω–∏—Ç—å, –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –ø—Ä–∏–Ω—è—Ç—å.

Cute little escape room game with entertaining puzzles, beautiful pixel art and cozy yet creepy atmoshpere!

Worth at full price, even if it is short (took me 3 hours, but replaying took me 40 mins to finish)

This is peak video game design. Atmospheric and immersive world. Immensely fun, clever, but not too hard puzzles makes this a smooth and seamless escape room experience you should NOT miss! This game needs to be even more clear that is barely anything more than a Clicker game, but not one you can leave alone.  It highlights the texting-based story, but has about as much plot as Cookie Clicker.  Also easy to miss, as they come randomly about 20 minutes apart.  Not sure who it's for, as the automation takes a while to get to but the complexity build-up or the setup is not at all rewarding.  Machines locked until further progress are not visible in any way, have no indicator of when you can get them or what you're working/waiting for, giving no sense or clue of progress or development while you can't really leave it running, as machines have to be refilled every few minutes.  No chance of an autoclicker program either, as you click each 'automation' machine to refill them.

Like others have said, this is a Clicker game that won't do anything after a brief break in your presence and interaction in the game. | Love the gameplay. Unique blend of incremental and automation. 

HATE the "dialogue". Adds nothing to game and is poorly written. | On sale for 3 dollars US?? Easily worth it.

Biggest Downside? As the game progresses, resource generation becomes more punishing. Wish I had known that I would need read the wiki to get to a stable infinite gameplay spot. And that if I couldn't I'd need to restart my progression from the midgame. Probably won't finish the game because of that. 

I loved exploring the efficiencies, it just too punishing for testing out builds in the endgame to continue to be fun.

7/10 | doesn't feel rewarding or incentive to play.
The beginning is very grindy with almost no automation, and every early mistake can be quite punishing | I really wanted to like this game. I've spent the time to understand the mechanics, experiment with layouts, and optimize. But it was a one-sided effort, with the game feeling mostly frustrating and not rewarding. 

The main issue for me is the pacing. The game is a strange mix of a Factorio-like production optimization‚Äîbut without proper automation, until [i]much[/i] later in the game‚Äîand an idle clicker‚Äîbut still requiring attention and user input ever couple of minutes to refill the machines). With the addition of the (simulated) time passage when the game is closed, it feels like one of those microtransaction-filled mobile games, only someone removed the "pay to not wait" and "pay to improve resource storage" microtransactions and didn't replace them with anything. So I spend hours refilling machines and saving up for the next small‚Äîbut prohibitively expensive‚Äîpurchase.

The last nail in the coffin for me happened when [spoiler]I've reached Chromalit and got to a point where I even need to time when the resources are released, just to be able to do anything with them (since storage is way too expensive),[/spoiler] the whole experience became a total chore‚Äîwith no end in sight‚Äîand I just wasn't enjoying myself.

If you play it actively, it's a relatively short game. If you want something to leave open and check once in a while it's a great little game. Early on it require more active planting but the better crops you get, the less you'll need to come back. At some point you have an "upgrade" that make planting automatic too but less efficient than doing yourself. You'll unlock different maps if you want to keep going but beside a very small different for each it's all the same game over again, no unlocks or bonus for finishing a map. Only thing that would've been awesome - some kind of prestige after unlocking new farm and starting over. One thing that changes - farm layout, and it's okay and has it's quirks, but seems a bit underwhelming.
